revision.comment: Rescuing 12 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{redirect|Rosecroft|the historic house in San Diego|Rosecroft (San Diego)}} {{Infobox racecourse | name = Rosecroft Raceway | image = [[File:Rosecroft Front.jpg|250px|alt=A square building with red and white vertical striping along the roof. A banner on the front shows Rosecroft's logo and the statement "Welcome Back Racing Fans!"]] | caption = The front of the Rosecroft Raceway, in May 2012. | website = www.rosecroft.com | location = 6336 Rosecroft Drive
[[Fort Washington, Maryland]], United States | coordinates = | owner = The Stronach Group | opened = May 26, 1949; August 25, 2011 | closed = July 1, 2010 | channel = | racetype = [[Harness racing]] | coursetype = | notableraces = Maryland Sire Stakes | handle = {{Increase}} $842,763 (2011){{Harvnb|Maryland Racing Commission|2011|p=14}} | attendance = {{Decrease}} 135,138 (2009) }} '''Rosecroft Raceway''', nicknamed the '''"Raceway by the Beltway"''' for being close to [[Interstate 495 (Capital Beltway)|Interstate 495]], is a [[harness racing]] track in [[Fort Washington, Maryland]]. It first opened in 1949 and was owned by William E. Miller, a horse trainer and breeder. Rosecroft quickly became [[Prince George's County]]'s political and social center, drawing thousands of people there each racing day. In the early 1950s, average attendance was more than 7,000 per day. After Miller died in 1954, his son John owned Rosecroft until his death in 1969. Rosecroft hosted memorial stake races annually for both William and John until 1995. Following the death of John Miller, Earle Brown controlled operations until he moved to a different position in 1980; William E. Miller II took over following Brown. Rosecroft was sold to Mark Vogel in 1987. Vogel made several mistakes that hurt the horse racing industry in Maryland. Three years later, he was arrested for possession of [[cocaine]], and his company went into bankruptcy. Rosecroft was sold to Weisman's Colt Enterprises in 1991. In that same year, the [[grandstand]] caught fire and was reconstructed in 1993 for $3.6 million. In 1995, after losing millions, the relatives of Weisman sold Rosecroft to Cloverleaf Enterprises. In the 2000s, Cloverleaf attempted to sell Rosecroft multiple times, but due to [[lawsuits]] and politics, all the potential buyers became uninterested. Nearby states legalized [[casino]]s to help their racetracks. Money generated from the casinos was used to increase the purses and handle (daily betting turnover), and Rosecroft was unable to produce the same amount of money. After filing for bankruptcy once again, Rosecroft Raceway closed down in 2010. The next year, [[Penn National Gaming]] purchased the racetrack with the hope to make it a [[racino]], and Rosecroft reopened in 2011. Throughout Rosecroft's history, it has featured notable races. From 1984 to 1988, it hosted segments of the [[Breeders Crown]]. Starting in 1990 and ending in 1995, the racetrack hosted the [[Messenger Stakes]], the second leg of the [[Triple Crown of Harness Racing for Pacers]]. Rosecroft hosted the Potomac Stakes, Maryland most successful harness race, from 1990 to 1992. Rosecroft features the Maryland Sire Stakes, which showcases the best [[standardbred]] horses in Maryland. Besides the races, Rosecroft has had famous people and horses work and race at the track. John Wager, Maryland's all-time most winning driver, has been working at Rosecroft since 1974. Several famous people—[[Lyndon B. Johnson]], [[Elizabeth Taylor]], and [[Nancy Pelosi]], among others—have visited Rosecroft. [[Cam's Card Shark]] raced at Rosecroft in 1994 and challenged the single-season record for most money won in a season by winning over $2 million, and [[Robust Hanover]] set a track record while winning the Breeders Crown in 1985. {{TOC limit|2}} == History == === Miller family: 1947–1987 === [[File:Rosecroft Raceway Opening Night May 27, 1949.png|thumb|left|Rosecroft Raceway's opening night, May 27, 1949. An estimated 6,000 people were in attendance, and $164,501 was wagered. Also, this picture shows the first version of the grandstand, which would be remodeled twice during its history.|alt=A black and white photograph depicting a race at Rosecroft. Six horses are making a turn, and 6,000 people are watching.]] In September 1947, a meeting was held about bringing a harness racetrack to Maryland, specifically [[Prince George's County, Maryland|Prince George's County]],{{Cite news | title=Harness Race Hearings Set | newspaper=[[The Baltimore Sun]] | page=11 | date=September 11, 1947}} and Rosecroft was chosen to be the site.{{Cite news | title=Oxon Hill Ok'd by Race Board | newspaper=The Washington Post | date=March 6, 1949 | page=C2}} William E. Miller—a future [[Harness Racing Museum & Hall of Fame|harness racing Immortal]]{{Cite web | url=http://www.harnessmuseum.com/pages/hall-of-fame/Immortals/immortals_3.htm | title=Immortals L – Po | publisher=[[Harness Racing Museum & Hall of Fame]] | accessdate=July 22, 2012 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110911223217/http://www.harnessmuseum.com/pages/hall-of-fame/Immortals/immortals_3.htm# | archive-date=2011-09-11 | dead-url=yes | df= }} and [[Horse breeding|horse breeder]]—founded Rosecroft Raceway in 1949.{{Harvnb|Branch-Miles|Thomas|Woods|2005|p=108}}{{Harvnb|Evans|1976|p=81}} It was the first raceway to be owned by horse owners, [[horse trainer]]s, and jockeys. Rosecroft was originally the WE Miller Stables and was located next to the Rosecroft Stock Farm, where horses were bred.{{Harvnb|Branch-Miles|Thomas|Woods|2005|p=109}} The racetrack cost $800,000 to construct and was "first class in every respect".{{Cite news | last=McKenna | first=Dave | date=December 16, 2011 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/699pD0aEQ?url=http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/articles/41862/rosecrofts-long-shot-live-racing-has-made-an-unlikely-comeback/# | archivedate=2012-07-14 | url=http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/articles/41862/rosecrofts-long-shot-live-racing-has-made-an-unlikely-comeback/ | title=Rosecroft's Long Shot | newspaper=[[Washington City Paper]] | accessdate=April 8, 2012 | dead-url=no | df= }} ''[[The Washington Post]]'' estimated a crowd of 12,000 on its opening day of May 26, 1949, but rain cancelled the races.{{cite web | last=Bojarski | first=Tim | date=May 30, 2012 | url=http://xwebapp.ustrotting.com/absolutenm/templates/hoofbeats_blog.aspx?articleid=48355&zoneid=75 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/699pGK5DX?url=http://xwebapp.ustrotting.com/absolutenm/templates/hoofbeats_blog.aspx?articleid=48355# | archivedate=2012-07-14 | title=Happy Birthday, Rosecroft Raceway | work=Hoof Beats | publisher=[[United States Trotting Association]] | accessdate=July 4, 2012 | dead-url=no | df= }} Rosecroft's first night of racing was May 27, 1949 when 6,000 people showed up and $164,501 was wagered.{{Cite news | title=New Harness Track Opens | newspaper=Middletown Times Herald | date=May 28, 1949 | page=12}} The handle was the second-highest ever recorded for a night trotting track on an opening night. For years, Rosecroft Raceway held an annual sale of [[Yearling (horse)|yearling]] [[Standardbred]] horses. It hosted the annual Maryland Sire Stake Races to promote the best of Maryland-bred horses.{{Harvnb|Branch-Miles|Thomas|Woods|2005|p=111}} When Rosecroft opened, it became the political and social center for Prince George's County, Maryland.{{cite journal | last=Miller II | first=William | url=http://www.rosecroft.com/pages/history-of-rosecroft-raceway | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/699pJDOYA?url=http://www.rosecroft.com/pages/history-of-rosecroft-raceway# | archivedate=2012-07-14 | title=Remembering Rosecroft | journal=The Horseman & Fair World | pages=16–19 | date=January 2011 | accessdate=May 24, 2012 | dead-url=no | df= }} Each year during the Miller era, several thousand people traveled from across the country to wager on and watch the horses.{{Cite news | title=Betting and Attendance at Rosecroft Raceway well Ahead of Last Year | newspaper=The Baltimore Sun | date=May 28, 1951 | page=18}}{{Cite news | title=Trot Meets Set Records | newspaper=The Baltimore Sun | date=December 6, 1963 | page=S10}} In 1953, Rosecroft's attendance of 192,585 was the highest among all harness tracks in Maryland.{{Cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Ms4mAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jAIGAAAAIBAJ&dq=baltimore%20raceway%20maryland%20attendance&pg=1059%2C4762113 | title=Brandywine Second in Attendance | newspaper=Wilmington Sunday Star | page=37 | date=December 6, 1953 | accessdate=June 4, 2012}} Owners, trainers, and drivers from across the United States moved their farms to Maryland in the 1950s following the opening of Rosecroft, hoping to compete with the best horses.{{Cite news | title=Maryland Ready for Harness Racing | newspaper=Cumberland Evening Times | date=May 16, 1950 | page=18}} In 1954, William E. Miller died from a heart attack while driving a horse at [[Harrington Raceway & Casino|Harrington Raceway]]. After Miller's death, Rosecroft hosted the William E. Miller Memorial race.{{Cite news | title=Big Race Set at Rosecroft | newspaper=The Baltimore Sun | date=December 26, 1954 | page=6D}} Over the years, this race attracted several notable horses, including [[Cam's Card Shark]], the 1994 Horse of the Year.{{Cite news | last=Nowakowski | first=Jack | date=May 15, 1994 | title=Cam{{'}}s Card Shark Ties Record in Miller Pace | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=D13}}{{Cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/08/29/sports/harness-racing-favorite-in-cane-pace-runs-far-from-perfect.html | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/699pNoPPz?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1994/08/29/sports/harness-racing-favorite-in-cane-pace-runs-far-from-perfect.html# | archivedate=2012-07-14 | title=Favorite in Cane Pace Runs Far from Perfect | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=August 29, 1994 | accessdate=May 25, 2012 | dead-url=no | df= }}{{Cite web | url=http://www.sboanj.com/stallion-peds/cams-card-shark-06.pdf | title=Cam{{'}}s Card Shark | format=PDF | publisher=Standardbred Breeders & Owners Association of New Jersey | accessdate=July 13, 2012}} John W. Miller, William's son, owned Rosecroft until his death in 1969.{{Cite news | title=Harness Track President John W. Miller, Dies at 58 | newspaper=The Baltimore Sun | date=May 8, 1969 | page=A21}} In 1961, the owners of Rosecroft resurfaced and regraded the track.{{Cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HgNOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QIwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6417,4020760&dq=rosecroft+raceway+governor%27s+day&hl=en | title=Grand Circuit to Stop at Rosecroft Next Week | newspaper=The Free Lance-Star | date=May 26, 1962 | page=8}} Following John, Earle Brown owned the racetrack. John Wager, Maryland's all-time most winning driver, started to work at Rosecroft in 1974. Earle Brown moved to a different position at the racetrack in 1980 and William E. Miller II, William E. Miller's grandson, took over operations. In 1984, the Hambletonian Society created the [[Breeders Crown]], a traveling series of races to showcase the best 2-year-old and 3-year-old horses throughout North American and Canada.{{Cite web | url=http://www.hambletonian.org/archive_breeders_crown_history.html | title=The Breeders Crown History: 1948–2012 | publisher=Hambletonian Society | accessdate=November 28, 2012 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107134630/http://www.hambletonian.org/archive_breeders_crown_history.html# | archive-date=2012-11-07 | dead-url=yes | df= }}{{Cite web | url=http://theharnessedge.com/pdf/BreedersCrownHostTracks.pdf | title=Breeders Crown Host Tracks | work=The Harness Edge | accessdate=July 18, 2012}} In the inaugural year, Rosecroft was awarded with a race. Rosecroft hosted the 2-Year-Old Pace of the 1985 Breeders Crown, where [[Robust Hanover]] won.{{Cite news | last=Clippinger | first=Don | date=December 27, 1985 | title=Garden State Gets Harness Series | newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] | page=C7}} === Mark Vogel: 1987–1990 === [[File:Rosecroft-Raceway-Before-1991.jpg|thumb|right|Rosecroft Raceway pictured with the older grandstand. When Mark Vogel purchased the racetrack, he envisioned a new, $10 million grandstand.|alt=Picture of Rosecroft's track and old grandstand. A horse is racing on the track. To the right, there are several rows of bleachers with a metal tent above for protection.]] Mark Vogel, a Maryland [[Real estate broker|real estate agent]], purchased both Rosecroft and [[Casino at Ocean Downs|Ocean Downs Racetrack]] in 1987 for $6 million in cash plus $5.5 million in debt.{{Cite journal | last=Bergstein | first=Stanley | date=November 23, 1987 | url=http://www.harnesstracks.com/docdatabase/htamembers/3883.pdf | title=Rosecroft Sold, Present Management Team to Remain | journal=Weekly Track Topics | publisher=Harness Tracks of America | page=2 | accessdate=July 14, 2012}} Rosecroft was awarded another Breeders Crown race in 1988, making it their fifth straight—but final—year of hosting them. Vogel had three main goals when he became owner: to construct a $10 million grandstand,{{Cite news | last=Nowakowski | first=Jack | date=February 19, 1988 | title=Vogel Plans New Grandstand, Bigger Track at Rosecroft | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=C3}} [[simulcast]] Rosecroft races at other racetracks throughout Maryland to attract a larger market,{{Cite news | last=Nowakowski | first=Jack | date=August 9, 1989 | title=Vogel Eyes Simulcast of Rosecroft Races | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=F10}} and have more racing days. In 1989, Vogel purchased Freestate Raceway.{{Cite news | last=Smith | first=C. Fraser | date=October 2, 1990 | url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1990-10-02/news/1990275062_1_vogel-two-tracks-sandler | title=Vogel, in Debt, Seeks to Sell 2 Tracks | newspaper=The Baltimore Sun | accessdate=July 5, 2012}} Freestate was sold to a development firm the next year, and Rosecroft was awarded more racing days.{{Cite news | last=Perrone | first=Vinnie | date=January 31, 1990 | title=It's Final: Freestate Is No More; Commission Grants Request to Transfer '90 Dates to Rosecroft | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=F10}} According to ''[[The Washington Times]]'' writer Rick Snyder, Vogel did not know the horse racing business and made mistakes that negatively affected the industry in Maryland. The year-round racing Rosecroft was awarded lowered the excitement for the locals. Rosecroft was not capable of attracting a new market, and attendance figures declined. He never focused on marketing or daily operations of Rosecroft. Instead, Vogel focused more on his real estate business. As a result, the attendance dropped. Vogel took out money from the [[parimutuel betting#Parimutuel bet types|betting pools]] to help his real estate business. Lower betting pools mean smaller payouts for the bettors and less profit for the racetrack owners. Vogel never formed political ties to help pass legislation used to help harness racing, more specially to allow [[off-track betting]] and to lower the [[State taxation in the united states|state tax]] on betting pools.{{Cite news | last=Snider | first=Rick | date=October 3, 1990 | title=Vogel should have Focused more on the Horse Business | newspaper=[[The Washington Times]] | page=D4}} Starting in 1990, Rosecroft Raceway hosted the [[Messenger Stakes]], one of the races for the [[Triple Crown of Harness Racing for Pacers]].{{Cite news | last=Grove | first=Bob | date=April 14, 1995 | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UXReAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9GENAAAAIBAJ&pg=1511,5851378&dq=messenger+stakes+rosecroft+raceway&hl=en | title=Meadows Lands the Messenger Stakes | newspaper=[[Observer-Reporter]] | page=C1 | accessdate=May 9, 2012}} Rosecroft attracted the Potomac Stakes, Maryland's most successful race, starting in that year. The Potomac Stakes was previously held at Freestate Raceway and generated one-million-dollar-plus handles on several occasions.{{Cite news | last=Nowakowski | first=Jack | date=July 21, 1990 | title=Rich Potomac makes Debut at Rosecroft | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=D9}} On a September 1990 night, $1,195,681 was wagered by bettors, becoming the then-largest handle in Rosecroft's history. This record was broken on May 3, 2003 when $1,564,150 was wagered.{{Harvnb|United States Trotting Association|2012|p=25}} Vogel was arrested in September 1990 for possession of [[cocaine]], and his company filed for bankruptcy protection.{{Cite news | url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1990-09-23/news/1990266095_1_schmoke-mosley-burns | title=Track Owner Vogel, Arrested on Cocaine Charges, Leaves | newspaper=The Baltimore Sun | date=September 23, 1990 | accessdate=May 23, 2012}}{{Cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=M7FYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NosDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1002,674289&dq=rosecroft+bankrupt&hl=en | title=Vogel's Real Estate Partnership Files for Bankruptcy Protection | newspaper=[[The Free Lance–Star]] | date=September 27, 1990 | page=33 | accessdate=May 23, 2012}} === Weisman's Colt Enterprises: 1991–1995 === [[File:Rosecroft Grandstand 2010.jpg|thumb|left|The new grandstand of Rosecroft, completed in 1993, features giant windows. Rosecroft officials reached new simulcasting agreements during the reconstruction. As a result, several big-screen televisions were added throughout.|alt=Rosecroft's new grandstand, which features giants windows.]] In 1991, two people were interested in buying the track: Fred Weisman, a California businessman, and former [[National Football League]] player [[Mark May]]. Weisman out-bid May and purchased Rosecroft out of bankruptcy for $18.2 million.{{Cite news | last=Snider | first=Rick | title=Weisman's $18.2 Million Bid for Rosecroft Accepted | newspaper=The Washington Times | date=June 4, 1991 | page=D4}} On November 23 of the same year, the grandstand caught fire a few hours before live racing began.{{Cite news | last1=Armacost | first1=Elisa | last2=Peddicord | first2=Ross | date=November 24, 1991 | title=4 Hurt Battling 3-alarm Blaze at Oxon Hill Track Rosecroft Raceway Grandstand Damaged | url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1991-11-24/news/1991328054_1_rosecroft-raceway-harness-racing-grandstand | work=The Baltimore Sun | accessdate=January 16, 2012}} In Weisman's first full season of operations, Rosecroft experienced a 10.5 percent increase in handle and an 8.3 percent increase in attendance.{{Cite news | last=Nowaskowski | first=Jack | date=May 19, 1992 | title=Rosecroft Has Upswing in Recent Meet; Handle, Attendance both Up from 1991 | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=E7}} In 1992, [[Western Hanover]], the richest horse of that year, won two of the three Triple Crown races, including the Messenger Stakes at Rosecroft.{{Cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Gi1iAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xHYNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6001,3467679&dq=rosecroft+raceway&hl=en | title=Sidelines: Western Hanover Wins | newspaper=Observer-Reporter | page=C5 | date=September 13, 1992}} Rosecroft Raceway went into the record books on October 10, 1992, when a three-horse [[List of dead heat horse races|dead heat]] occurred in the seventh race. It was the 17th time in harness-racing history and the first time in Maryland history.{{Cite news | last=Nowakowski | first=Jack | date=October 12, 1992 | title=Three Horses in Dead Heat at Rosecroft | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=B12}} The new grandstand was completed for $3.6 million in 1993. Since Rosecroft had expanded its simulcasting rights,{{Cite news | last=Nowakowski | first=Jack | date=December 8, 1993 | title=Rosecroft to Expand Simulcast Network | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=B9}} the new grandstand incorporated [[Large-screen television technology|large-screen television]]s and betting windows.{{Cite news | last=Nowakowski | first=Jack | date=December 28, 1993 | title=Grand Opening for Rosecroft's Stands | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=E8}} For the 1993 season, Rosecroft's officials decided to stop hosting the five stake races—The Potomac, the Lady Baltimore, The Terrapan, The Turtle Dove, and The North American—inherited when Freestate Raceway closed. The handle was decreasing, and the officials could not afford the purses for the races.{{Cite news | last=Nowakowski | first=Jack | date=September 1, 1992 | title=Rosecroft to Drop Five Stakes Races | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=E7}} To help increase the handle, Maryland racetrack officials voted to allow inter-track simulcasting between all Maryland tracks and authorized off-track betting parlors throughout the state.{{Cite news | last=Peddicord | first=Ross | date=October 4, 1993 | title=Tracks Pull on Simulcast Handle OTB, Intertrack Boosting Betting for Laurel, Pimlico | newspaper=The Baltimore Sun | page=10C}} In September 1994, Weisman died from [[pancreatic cancer]] in Los Angeles, and his relatives took over the racetrack.{{Cite news | last=Perrone | first=Vinnie | date=September 15, 1994 | title=Owner of Rosecroft, Delmarva Dies; Without Weisman, Future of Maryland Harness Tracks a Mystery | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=B8}} Although attendance and handle were increasing, the owners were losing money. Reports by independent auditors stated Rosecroft and Ocean Downs combined to lose $1.1 million in [[fiscal year]] (FY) 1992, $1.4 million in FY 1993, and $6.2 million in FY 1994.{{Cite news | last=Perrone | first=Vinnie | date=March 19, 1994 | title=Harness Handles Up, Losses Down; But Audit Puts Rosecroft–Delmarva Deficit at $1.4 Million | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=G9}}{{Cite news | last=Perrone | first=Vinnie | date=May 12, 1994 | title=Harness Tracks Report a Losing Trend | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=D8}}{{Cite news | last=Perrone | first=Vinnie | date=April 1, 1995 | title=Closing of Rosecroft Threatened for June; Owners Say Horsemen must Buy the Track | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=H8}} According to Rosecroft's racing official Allan Levey, Weisman's relatives did not want to operate the track and their only goal was to sell it. For the 1995 season, Rosecroft could not afford the payment to host five stake races—including the Messenger Stakes—and dropped them from the racing schedule.{{Cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-03-25/sports/sp-46808_1_rosecroft-raceway | title=Rosecroft Raceway Can't Afford Messenger Stakes | date=March 29, 1995 | newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] | accessdate=May 9, 2012}}{{Cite news | last=Nowakiwski | first=Jack | date=March 24, 1995 | title=Five Major Races Gone At Rosecroft | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=B10}} === Cloverleaf Enterprises: 1995–2010 === [[File:Rosecroft-Total-Bets.png|thumb|right|A chart showing the betting revenue at Rosecroft from 2002 to 2010, which decreased 90% during this period.{{Cite news | last=McCalley | first=Mark | date=December 7, 2011 | url=http://cnsmaryland.org/2011/12/07/maryland-horse-racings-last-legs/ | title=Maryland Horse Racing's Last Legs? | newspaper=Capital News Service | accessdate=July 4, 2012}} Also, attendance decreased by 95% from 2002 to 2010.{{Harvnb|Maryland Racing Commission|2010|p=14}}{{Harvnb|Maryland Racing Commission|2005|p=14}}|alt=A chart with an x-axis of year, starting from 2002 and ending in 2010, and a y-axis of Total Betting Revenue, starting from $0 and ending at $120,000,000. The graph starts up high, and decreases almost toward the bottom.]] Throughout 1995, Rosecroft was forced to cut costs. Its owners lowered the amount of purse money, eliminated stake races, and reduced the number of racing days. They decided to sell both Rosecroft and Ocean Downs to Cloverleaf Enterprises, a horseman's organization, in mid-1995 for $11 million. Weisman's Colt Enterprises reported that if the racetrack could not be sold, the company would have to file for bankruptcy.{{Cite news | last=Perrone | first=Vinnie | date=March 18, 1995 | title=Rosecroft Owners May File for Bankruptcy | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=H10}} Cloverleaf accepted a $10.6 million loan from [[Bally Entertainment]] in hopes that a casino would be allowed at Rosecroft.{{Cite news | last=Perrone | first=Vinnie | date=June 30, 1995 | title=Maryland Board Approves Sale; Casino and Racing Groups Team to Buy Rosecroft, Delmarva | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=B9}} In 1994, the [[Delaware General Assembly]] approved [[slot machines]] for the state's three racetracks,{{Cite web | url=http://www.americangaming.org/industry-resources/state-information/delaware | title=Delaware | publisher=[[American Gaming Association]] | accessdate=July 12, 2012 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120516091958/http://www.americangaming.org/industry-resources/state-information/delaware# | archive-date=2012-05-16 | dead-url=yes | df= }} and the first [[racino]] opened in December 1995.{{Cite web | url=http://gaming.unlv.edu/abstract/de_main.html | title=Delaware Gaming Summary | publisher=[[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]] | date=June 22, 2012 | accessdate=July 23, 2012}} This helped the horse racing industry in Delaware, as approximately 10 percent of all gross revenue is used to increase the purses.{{Cite web | url=http://www.delottery.com/games/video/ | title=And They're Off! Video Lottery at Delaware Racetracks | publisher=Delaware Lottery | accessdate=July 23, 2012}} This drew competition away from Maryland. Rosecroft could not fill up a 12-race card for its opening night during the 1996 season.{{Cite news | last1=Perrone | first1=Vinnie | last2=Nowakowski | first2=Jack | date=February 1, 1996 | title=Rosecroft Trying to Stay Ahead of the Game; New Season Starts Gloomily With Competition From Dover, Difficulties Filling Live Cards | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=D1}} An estimated $80 million in wagering was lost in 1996 from the effect of Delaware's casinos.{{Cite news | last=Snyder | first=Rick | date=February 16, 1996 | title=Facing an estimated wagering loss of $80 million | newspaper=The Washington Times | page=B6}} Throughout the years, various politicians tried to bring slot machines or [[table game]]s to Rosecroft, but all were unsuccessful.{{Cite news | last=Snyder | first=Rick | date=February 22, 1996 | title=Bill to allow slot machines at Md. tracks might be presented today, sources say | newspaper=The Washington Times | page=B5}}{{Cite news | last=Mosher | first=James | date=April 11, 2006 | title=Slots in Md. Still a Possibility? | newspaper=[[Daily Record (Maryland)|Daily Record]] | page=1}}{{Cite news | url=http://dailycaller.com/2010/03/25/md-senate-approves-gambling-at-rosecroft-raceway/ | title=Md. Senate Approves Gambling at Rosecroft Raceway | newspaper=[[The Daily Caller]] | date=March 25, 2010 | accessdate=July 4, 2012}} In the 2000s, Cloverleaf tried to sell Rosecroft multiple times. In mid-2002, several buyers became interested in the track, but Cloverleaf was involved in [[lawsuits]], so the track could not be sold.{{Harvnb|Sanelli|2008|p=2}} One bidder was [[Peter Angelos]], the owner of the [[Baltimore Orioles]], but he withdrew in 2005.{{Cite news | last=Keyser | first=Tom | date=February 18, 2005 | url=http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/26732/angelos-family-withdraws-offer-for-rosecroft | title=Angelos' Family Withdraws Offer for Rosecroft | newspaper=[[The Blood-Horse]] | accessdate=July 2, 2012}} All the lawsuits were resolved in 2006, and only one remaining bidder was left—[[Penn National Gaming]]. Maryland passed a casino bill in 2007, but Rosecroft was not one of the locations sanctioned for expanded gambling by the law.{{cite web | url=http://slots.mdlottery.com/faq/ | title=Frequently Asked Questions | publisher=[[Maryland Lottery]] | accessdate=May 30, 2012}} As a result, Penn National lost its interest in Rosecroft and decided not to purchase the track. From the gambling revenue, 7 percent goes to the horse-racing industry. Cloverleaf announced Rosecroft would close on July 1, 2010.{{Cite news | last=Cho | first=Hanah | date=June 16, 2010 | title=Rosecroft Raceway to Close July 1 | url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2010-06-16/business/bs-bz-rosecroft-closing-20100616_1_cloverleaf-enterprises-cloverleaf-standardbred-owners-association-kelley-rogers | newspaper=The Baltimore Sun | accessdate=January 16, 2012}}{{Cite news | last=Robbins | first=Lindsey | date=June 18, 2010 | title=Bankrupt Rosecroft Raceway's Finish Line is July 1 | url=http://ww2.gazette.net/stories/06182010/businew174458_32552.php | newspaper=Maryland Gazette | accessdate=January 16, 2012}} Live racing ended in 2009,{{Cite news | url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20110506006051/en/Penn-National-Gaming-Seeks-Approval-Return-Live | title=Penn National Gaming Seeks Approval to Return Live Standardbred Racing and Year-Round Simulcasting to Rosecroft Raceway in July | newspaper=[[Business Wire]] | date=May 6, 2011 | accessdate=October 25, 2012}} and the track only had simulcasts as revenue from off-track betting. After several of the surrounding states legalized casinos, Rosecroft was unable to continue as a successful business.{{Cite journal | last=Scheinman | first=John | url=http://www.grayson-jockeyclub.org/newsimages/ca_ky_steroid.pdf | title=Thoroughbred Unlikely but Possible at Rosecroft | journal=Thoroughbred Times | volume=24 | issue=20 | date=July 26, 2008 | page=2}} Cloverleaf Enterprises filed for [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 11]] bankruptcy in June 2009.{{Cite news | last=Robbins | first=Lindsey | date=June 11, 2009 | url=http://ww2.gazette.net/stories/06112009/busiplo130505_32522.shtml | title=Rosecroft Raceway, Citing Capital Needs, Files for Bankruptcy | publisher=''Maryland Gazette'' | accessdate=July 18, 2012}} Mark Vogel loaned the track $350,000 and offered to buy the track, but a bankruptcy court judge refused to approve the plan. Rosecroft officials had hoped that the [[Maryland General Assembly]] would approve legislation allowing casino-style gambling at Rosecroft, but that did not occur. In early June 2010, Cloverleaf filed for [[Chapter 7, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 7]] bankruptcy. === Penn National Gaming: 2011–2016 === [[File:HorsesRacingRosecroft8September2012.jpg|thumb|left|Horses racing at Rosecroft in 2012. This picture is from Rosecroft's first qualifying race of 2012.|alt=There are six horses racing at Rosecroft Raceway during a qualifying race.]] In January 2011, Penn National Gaming bought Rosecroft for $10.25 million.{{cite news | agency=Associated Press | date=January 29, 2011 | url=http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/61034/penn-national-gaming-to-buy-rosecroft | title=Penn National Gaming to Buy Rosecroft | work=The Blood-Horse | accessdate=June 1, 2012}} Penn National said it planned to return live racing and simulcast wagering to the track as well as pushing for changes in Maryland gaming laws allowing slots and table games.{{Cite news | url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/business/bs-bz-rosecroft-raceway-auction-20110128,0,5105060.story | title=Penn National to pay $10.25 million for Rosecroft Raceway | newspaper=The Baltimore Sun | date=January 28, 2011 | last=Cho | first=Hanah | accessdate=January 17, 2012}} Penn National said it was hoping to convince the state to allow slot machines at the track, even though voters did not approve Prince George's County as a gambling location. On July 28, 2011, the Maryland Racing Commission agreed to allow Penn National Gaming to secure a $1.4 million line of credit to cover operating losses at Rosecroft for fiscal years 2011 and 2012.{{Cite news | last=Walker | first=Andrea | title=Rosecroft to Resume Racing in Three Weeks | url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2011-07-29/business/bs-bz-rosecroft-reopen-20110729_1_eric-schippers-cloverleaf-standardbred-owners-association-craig-gegorek | newspaper=The Baltimore Sun | date=July 29, 2011 | accessdate=January 17, 2012}} Penn National said it was likely to incur $2.3 million in losses through 2013.{{Cite news | last=Robbins | first=Lindsey | title=Panel Approves Rosecroft Racing—With Strings | url=http://www.gazette.net/article/20110714/NEWS/707089686/1029/panel-approves-rosecroft-racing-with-strings&template=gazette | newspaper=Maryland Gazette | date=July 14, 2011 | accessdate=January 17, 2012 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715073608/http://www.gazette.net/article/20110714/NEWS/707089686/1029/panel-approves-rosecroft-racing-with-strings%26template%3Dgazette# | archive-date=2011-07-15 | dead-url=yes | df= }} Penn National wanted Rosecroft to begin simulcasting races in late August 2011. Disputes between tracks and simulcasters about revenues, however, led to a delay in reaching new agreements on broadcast rights. In the 2011, the Maryland legislature passed a bill that required all parties to enter into mediation. If mediation was not successful by October 1, 2011, then an [[arbitrator]] was required to help. To resolve a conflict of interest, Penn National sold its financial stake in the [[Maryland Jockey Club]]'s in July 2011.{{Cite news | last=Berkheimer | first=George | date=July 5, 2011 | url=http://www.bizmonthly.com/penn-national-parts-with-jockey-club-will-focus-on-rosecroft/ | title=Penn National Parts With Jockey Club, Will Focus on Rosecroft | newspaper=The Business Monthly | accessdate=July 9, 2012 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110921204059/http://www.bizmonthly.com/penn-national-parts-with-jockey-club-will-focus-on-rosecroft/# | archive-date=2011-09-21 | dead-url=yes | df= }} In August 2011, Rosecroft made public its plans for adding a casino at Rosecroft. It planned to destroy the grandstand and build a casino with approximately 4,700 slot machines alongside the track.{{Cite news | last=Wagner | first=John | date=August 7, 2011 | title=As Budget Challenges Persist, Prince George's Rethinks Casino Gambling | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-politics/as-budget-challenges-persist-prince-georges-rethinks-casino-gambling/2011/08/05/gIQAJNfE1I_story.html | newspaper=The Washington Post | accessdate=January 17, 2012}} An agreement on simulcasting of harness and [[quarter horse]] races was reached in August allowing Rosecroft to reopen on August 25, 2011.{{Cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-politics/rosecroft-raceway-to-reopen-thursday/2011/08/20/gIQABNmpSJ_story.html | last=Wagner | first=John | title=Rosecroft Raceway to Reopen Thursday | newspaper=The Washington Post | accessdate=December 22, 2011 | date=August 20, 2011}} Rosecroft owed $1.24 million in unpaid disbursements under its previous simulcast license, and the parties were negotiating about how much of this debt Penn National would pay. Rosecroft drew 400 to 500 patrons on its opening day. Penn National also announced its intent to spend $1 million in the coming year to renovate the property, which would include razing old horse barns, putting a new roof on the betting parlors, and upgrading the [[HVAC]] system.{{Cite news | url=http://www.gazette.net/article/20110901/NEWS/709019926/1010/rosecroft-raceway-draws-hundreds-on-reopening-day&template=gazette | last=Liu | first=Mimi | title=Rosecroft Raceway Draws Hundreds on Reopening Day | newspaper=Maryland Gazette | date=September 1, 2011 | accessdate=December 22, 2011}} {{Dead link |date=April 2017}} A bill was introduced into the Maryland General Assembly in 2012 which would allow a casino in Prince George's County. The two likely spots were [[National Harbor, Maryland|National Harbor]] or Rosecroft.{{Cite news | last=Wagner | first=John | date=March 27, 2012 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-politics/md-senate-approves-casino-bill/2012/03/27/gIQAVRlKeS_story.html | title=Maryland Senate Approves Casino Bill | newspaper=The Washington Post | accessdate=July 9, 2012}} The bill passed the Senate, but the House did not vote on it.{{Cite web | url=http://mlis.state.md.us/2012rs/billfile/sb0892.htm | title=Senate Bill 892 | publisher=[[Maryland General Assembly]] | date=June 26, 2012 | accessdate=August 1, 2012}} The bill was passed and signed by the Governor in August 2012 to allow a casino in Prince George's County, which was passed via [[referendum]] in November 2012.{{Cite news | last=Lambert | first=Jack | date=August 15, 2012 | url=http://www.bizjournals.com/baltimore/news/2012/08/15/maryland-casinos-how-the-states.html?page=all | title=Maryland Casinos: How the State's Gaming Industry Could Change | newspaper=Baltimore Business Journal | accessdate=October 25, 2012}}{{Cite news | last1=Bell | first1=Brad | last2=Gonzalez | first2=John | date=November 7, 2012 | url=http://www.wjla.com/articles/2012/11/maryland-gambling-question-7-passes-81805.html | title=Maryland Gambling Question 7 Passes | newspaper=''[[WJLA-TV]]'' | publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]] | accessdate=November 17, 2012}} After one season of live racing, Penn National and Cloverleaf reached an agreement to extend live racing at Rosecroft for the next two years. The only exception is if National Harbor becomes the location for the Prince George's County casino.{{Cite web | url=http://www.rosecroft.com/news/detail/2012/08/07/penn-national--csoa-annouce-contract-extensio | title=Penn National—CSOA Announce Contract Extension | publisher=Rosecroft Raceway | date=August 7, 2012 | accessdate=September 10, 2012}} ===Stronach Group: 2016-present=== In May 2016, the [[Stronach Group]] purchased Rosecroft Raceway for an undisclosed sum. The purchase closed on August 2, 2016. Stronach Group said it would make some cosmetic improvements to the racing facilities, and then begin an evaluation to see what long-term improvements it might make.{{cite news|last=Gordon|first=Joshua|title=Pimlico owner Stronach Group to purchase Rosecroft Raceway|work=Baltimore Business Journal|date=May 16, 2016|accessdate=May 17, 2016|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/news/2016/05/16/pimlico-ownerstronach-group-to-purchase-rosecroft.html}} == Non-horse racing activities == Besides horse racing, Rosecroft has allowed other activities. The Old School Boxing Gym is located there,{{Cite news | last=Policastro | first=Jason | date=July 8, 2010 | url=http://ww2.gazette.net/stories/07082010/lanhnew175433_32587.php | title=Refusing to Throw in the Towel | newspaper=Maryland Gazette | accessdate=July 2, 2012}} and the track has hosted [[amateur boxing]] matches for several years.{{cite web | last=Williams | first=Gary | url=http://boxingalongthebeltway.blogspot.com/2009/12/update-on-december-19-card-at-rosecroft.html | title=Update on December 19 Card at Rosecroft Raceway | publisher=Boxing Along the Beltway | date=December 14, 2009 | accessdate=July 2, 2012}}{{Cite news | title=P. Brown Looks to Progress at Rosecroft Event | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=E2 | date=May 18, 2007}} The gym served as a refuge to children in the area. Before his [[heavyweight]] championship tenure, [[George Foreman]] beat [[Sylvester Dullaire]] at Rosecroft on July 14, 1969.{{Cite news | last=Goldstein | first=Alan | date=July 15, 1969 | title=Foreman Knocks out Dullaire | newspaper=The Baltimore Sun | page=C1}} Then-undefeated boxer [[Seth Mitchell]] also fought at Rosecroft in 2009.{{Cite news | url=http://boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=435230&cat=boxer | title=Seth Mitchell | publisher=[[BoxRec]] | accessdate=July 11, 2012}} Rosecroft made news when it decided to host an all-female night of boxing in 2009.{{Cite news | last=Naji-Allah | first=Khalid | date=June 25, 2009 | url=http://washingtoninformer.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4251:new-smithsonian-exhibit-exposes-gullah-language&catid=64:entertainment&Itemid=136 | title=All-Female Boxing Card Held at Rosecroft | newspaper=[[The Washington Informer]] | accessdate=July 2, 2012}} In 1974, Rosecroft Raceway hosted professional motorcycle races.{{Cite news | title=Cycles at Rosecroft | date=April 19, 1974 | newspaper=The Baltimore Sun | page=C6}} In 2012, Rosecroft hosted the 46th Annual Cherry Blossom [[Rugby football|Rugby]] Tournament.{{cite web | url=http://www.nationalcherryblossomfestival.org/2012/02/11/46th-annual-cherry-blossom-rugby-tournament/ | title=46th Annual Cherry Blossom Rugby Tournament | publisher=National Cherry Blossom Festival | accessdate=July 2, 2012 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404043903/http://www.nationalcherryblossomfestival.org/2012/02/11/46th-annual-cherry-blossom-rugby-tournament/# | archive-date=2012-04-04 | dead-url=yes | df= }} The area also serves large banquets.{{Harvnb|The Innovation Group|2011|p=1}} Other community activities include an annual Senior Citizen Day, hosting [[flea markets]], fundraising for politicians, and hosting Governor's Day.{{Harvnb|Branch-Miles|Thomas|Woods|2005|pp=109–110}} == Construction == Rosecroft was built in 1949 on {{convert|125|acre|ha}}.{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/companyProfile?rpc=66&symbol=PENN.O | title=Penn National Gaming Inc (PENN.O) | publisher=[[Forbes]] | accessdate=May 9, 2012}} There are 2,500 parking spaces including main parking by the main entrance. It is nicknamed the "Raceway by the Beltway" for being close to [[Interstate 495 (Capital Beltway)|Interstate 495]].{{cite web | url=http://www.rosecroft.com/news/detail/2012/05/12/vincent-wins-five-on-saturday-nigh | title=Vincent Win Five on Saturday Night | publisher=Rosecroft Raceway | date=May 12, 2012 | accessdate=May 16, 2012 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67ib9UaV5?url=http://www.rosecroft.com/news/detail/2012/05/12/vincent-wins-five-on-saturday-nigh# | archivedate=2012-05-17 | dead-url=no | df= }} The track is 5/8-mile long and has a 700-foot home stretch.{{cite web | url=http://www.pngaming.com/About/Company%20Fact%20Sheet | title=Company Fact Sheet | publisher=[[Penn National Gaming]] | accessdate=May 9, 2012}} The current grandstand has been there since 1993. It is 53,000 square feet and is beside the 96,000 square foot, 3-story club house. Inside the club house is the terrace dining room, which holds up to 1,100 people.{{Cite book | title=Mid-Atlantic Country | volume=8 | publisher=Country Sun | year=1986 | page=41 | issn=0888-1022}} Each table in the dining room has its own television, which can be used to watch horse racing—either from Rosecroft or other tracks around the world.{{Harvnb|Solomon|Ruben|Aloisi|2007|p=286}} == Prominent visitors == * [[Thomas D'Alesandro]], former [[United States House of Representatives]] * [[Zsa Zsa Gabor]], Hungarian actress * [[George Foreman]], retired champion [[boxer]] * [[Parris Glendening]], former [[Governor of Maryland]]{{Harvnb|Branch-Miles|Thomas|Woods|2005|p=110}} * [[Lyndon B. Johnson]], former president of the United States{{Cite news | last=Snider | first=Rick | date=October 22, 2011 | url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/2011/10/rick-snider-theres-no-safe-bet-rosecroft-raceway/41253 | title=Rick Snider: There's No Safe Bet at Rosecroft Raceway | newspaper=The Washington Examiner | accessdate=June 1, 2012 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20120728202346/http://washingtonexaminer.com/2011/10/rick-snider-theres-no-safe-bet-rosecroft-raceway/41253# | archive-date=2012-07-28 | dead-url=yes | df= }} * [[Nancy Pelosi]], former Speaker of the US House of Representatives, current [[House Minority Leader]] * [[Jennings Randolph]], former [[United States Senator]] * [[Elizabeth Taylor]], British actress == Track records == {{Col-start}} {{Col-2}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |+ Pacers{{cite web | url=http://www.rosecroft.com/pages/rosecroft-raceway-track-records | title=Rosecroft Raceway Track Records | publisher=Rosecroft Raceway | accessdate=May 27, 2012}} |- ! revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=July 2009}} [[File:GBNYShotgun.jpg|thumb|right|330px|The [[Green Bay Packers]] (left) in the shotgun in a game against the [[New York Giants]] in [[2007 NFL season|2007]]]]
The '''shotgun formation''' is a [[Formation (American football)|formation]] used by the [[offensive team]] in [[American football|American]] and [[Canadian football]]. This formation is used mainly for passing plays, although some teams use it as their base formation. In the shotgun, instead of the [[quarterback]] receiving the [[Snap (football)|snap]] from [[center (American football)|center]] at the [[line of scrimmage]], he stands farther behind the line of scrimmage, often five to seven yards back. Sometimes the quarterback will have a back on one or both sides before the snap, while other times he will be the lone player in the backfield with everyone spread out as receivers.
The shotgun formation can offer certain advantages. The offensive linemen have more room to maneuver behind the scrimmage line and form a tighter, more cohesive oval “pocket” in which the quarterback is protected from “blitzing” by the defense. If the quarterback has speed, mobility or both, he can use this formation to scramble before his pass; or, to run to an open field position in the defensive secondary or to the sideline, usually gaining first-down yardage.
The formation also has weaknesses. The defense knows a pass is more than likely coming up (although some running plays can be run effectively from the shotgun) and there is a higher risk of a botched snap than in a simple center/quarterback exchange. If the defense is planning a pass rush, this formation gives fast defensive players more open and exposed targets in the offensive backfield, with less cluttered “blitzing” routes to the quarterback and any other [[Halfback (American football)|halfback]] in the offensive backfield.
Shotgun combines elements of the [[short punt formation|short punt]] and spread formations — "spread" in that it has receivers spread widely instead of close to or behind the interior line players. The origins of the term are thought to be that it is like a "shotgun" in spraying receivers around the field.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1184750-25-craziest-football-terms-and-where-they-come-from|title=BleacherReport, Craziest Football Terms and Where They Come From}}</ref> (The alignment of the players also suggests the shape of an actual shotgun.) Formations similar or identical to the shotgun used decades previously would be called names such as "spread double wing". Short punt formations (so called because the distance between the snapper and the ostensible punter is shorter than in long punt formation) do not usually have as much emphasis on wide receivers.
[[File:Shotgun Formation.svg|thumb|350px|right|A typical Shotgun formation—many variables can be modified, but this is the basic setup many teams use]]
==History==
The shotgun evolved from the [[single wing]] and the similar double-wing spread; famed [[triple threat man]] [[Sammy Baugh]] has claimed that the shotgun was effectively the same as the version of the double-wing he ran at [[TCU Horned Frogs football|Texas Christian University]] in the 1930s.<ref>David, Howard and Johnny Unitas (1981?). "History of the Forward Pass". [[Mizlou Television Network]]. Available at FrontRowSportsEntertainment.com; retrieved 2010-05-24.</ref>
In the latter part of the 1940s, the Philadelphia Eagles, under Hall of Fame Coach Earl "Greasy" Neale, implemented the shotgun formation in their offensive attack with quarterback Tommy Thompson.
The formation was named by the man who actually devised it, [[San Francisco 49ers]] coach [[Red Hickey]], in 1960.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/mar/31/local/me-passings31.2 | title=Red Hickey, 89; NFL Player, Coach Invented Shotgun Formation | publisher=Los Angeles Times | date=2006-03-31 | accessdate=2012-05-29}}</ref> [[John Brodie]] was the first NFL shotgun quarterback, beating out former starter [[Y. A. Tittle]] largely because he was mobile enough to effectively run the formation.
The [[New York Jets]] briefly experimented with the shotgun during the middle of the [[Joe Namath]] era to give the bad-kneed and often immobile quarterback more time to set up plays by placing him deeper in the backfield. Three years before Dallas ushered in the modern era of the shotgun to the NFL, [[Joe Theismann]] of the [[Toronto Argonauts]] regularly employed the formation north of the border in the CFL. <ref> "Tell me to my Face", by Angelo Mosca with Steve Milton, Lulu Publishing, 2011 </ref> But the formation was not used on a regular basis in the NFL until the 1975 season, and then only by the [[Dallas Cowboys]], who used the shotgun frequently with [[Roger Staubach]] at quarterback. The Cowboy shotgun differed from the 49er shotgun as Staubach generally had a back next to him in the backfield (making runs possible), where Brodie was normally alone in the backfield.
Since no other NFL teams used the formation during this time, some believed it had been invented by [[Tom Landry]]. Instead, Landry simply dusted off the old innovation to address a pressing problem: keeping Staubach protected while an unusually young and inexperienced squad (12 rookies made the 1975 Cowboys roster) jelled. The Cowboys ended up in the Super Bowl that season, in no small part due to its new use of the old formation. The shotgun became a "signature" formation for the Cowboys, especially during third down situations.
The shotgun was adopted by more teams throughout the pass-happy late 1980s, and was part of almost every team's offense in the 1990s, eventually becoming a base formation for some teams in the late 2000s.
==Recent use==
In recent years, the shotgun has become vastly prevalent. Many college quarterbacks—such as [[Tim Tebow]], who almost exclusively used the shotgun at [[Florida Gators football|Florida]]—have difficulty adapting to NFL offenses where about a third of snaps are taken under center. However, with the [[spread offense]] increasingly used in the NFL, the shotgun is more popular, since the spread allows for more effective running. [[File:Patriots on offense at Super Bowl XXXIX 1.jpg|thumb|left|[[Tom Brady]] in the shotgun at a Super Bowl.]] The shotgun formation is often run during 2nd-and-long or 3rd-and-long situations to give the quarterback enough time to allow the receivers to run deep routes. However, [[Peyton Manning]], formerly of the [[Indianapolis Colts]], often [[Quarterback#Special_tactics|audibled]] to plays that use this formation in order to better read defenses and to take advantage of fast receivers like [[Marvin Harrison]] and [[Reggie Wayne]] and gain extended yardage in a single play. In 2007, the [[New England Patriots]] used the shotgun with great effectiveness as a base formation for the offense that scored the then-record 587 points in a 16-game season<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=11 December 2012|url=http://www.coldhardfootballfacts.com/content/greatest-scoring-offenses-all-nfl-history/6100/|title=Cold Hard Football Facts - Greatest Scoring Offenses, all of NFL history|publisher=Cold Hard Football Facts}}</ref> (since broken by the [[Denver Broncos]] in [[2013 Denver Broncos season|2013]]); in fact, the 2007 Patriots were the first team in NFL history to use it for the majority of their offensive plays.<ref>[http://www.boston.com/sports/football/articles/2008/08/24/players_must_pull_together/?page=full Players must pull together] Boston.com Football Notes</ref> The Patriots have also used the formation to directly snap the ball away from the quarterback, snapping it instead to a running back (usually [[Kevin Faulk]]); the Patriots scored a [[two-point conversion]] via such a direct snap to Faulk in [[Super Bowl XXXVIII]] and again against the [[2006 San Diego Chargers season|Chargers]] in the AFC Divisional Playoffs.
[[File:ShotgunFormationAFAvCSU.jpg|thumb|right|330px|Side view of the shotgun formation]]
Though the shotgun is a pass-dominated formation, a cleverly designed halfback [[draw play]] can put defenses off guard and a fast halfback can get good yardage before the defense recovers from their mistake. A further development of the play is a [[halfback option pass]], with the [[quarterback]] being one of the eligible receivers. [[Roger Staubach]]'s backup and successor, [[Danny White]], twice caught such a pass for a touchdown. It was noted at the time that he was only eligible because of the shotgun formation (an NFL quarterback who takes a snap from underneath the center was and still is an ineligible receiver, a rule not found in any amateur level of American football).
The shotgun is also used in college, but running is used more often than in the NFL. Most offenses in college who run in the shotgun have a fast quarterback. They often use a play where the quarterback has an option of handing the ball off to the running back who runs to the side opposite the side he was lined up on. The quarterback can also run the opposite way depending on how the defense reacts. [[Urban Meyer]] and the [[Florida Gators football|Florida Gators]] used this effectively from 2006 to 2009 with [[Tim Tebow]].
==Related formations==
The [[Nevada Wolf Pack football|Nevada Wolf Pack]] currently employs a formation called the "[[pistol offense|pistol]]", in which the running back, instead of lining up next to the quarterback, lines up behind the quarterback, who in turn has lined up two to three yards behind the center.
Coach [[Urban Meyer]] has added elements of the [[option offense]] to the shotgun offense he employed as coach at [[Bowling Green Falcons football|Bowling Green State University]], the [[Utah Utes football|University of Utah]], and [[Florida Gators football|University of Florida]]. This "[[Spread offensive|spread option]]" offense is also used by the [[Missouri Tigers football|Missouri Tigers]], [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State Buckeyes]] and other college teams with quarterbacks who can run as well as throw effectively.
==Use in Canadian football==
At times the formation has been more common in [[Canadian football]], which allows only three downs to move ten yards downfield instead of the American game's four.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=13 August 2011|url=https://www.cfl.ca/uploads/assets/CFL/publications/2008rulebook.pdf|title=CFL Official Playing Rules 2008|publisher=[[Canadian Football League|cfl.ca]]}}</ref> Canadian teams are therefore more likely to find themselves with long yardage to make on the penultimate down, and therefore more likely to line up in the shotgun to increase their opportunities for a large gain. Canadian teams also have the advantage that backs positioned behind the line of scrimmage can run forward and cross the line running as the ball is snapped.
==See also== {{Commonscat|Shotgun formation}} *[[American football strategy|Football strategy]] *[[Spread offense]] *[[Wildcat formation|Wildcat]] *[[Pistol offense]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{American football strategy}}
[[Category:American football formations]] [[Category:Canadian football terminology]]

{{infobox country at games | NPC = SIN | NPCname = [http://www.sdsc.org.sg/ Singapore Disability Sports Council] | games = Summer Paralympics | year = 1996 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = | location = [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]] | competitors = 3 | sports = 2 | flagbearer = | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = 1988 | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Singapore]]''' competed at the '''[[1996 Summer Paralympics]]''' in [[Atlanta]], [[United States]]. Three competitors from Singapore competed in a total of two sports (athletics and cycling), and did not place in the [[1996 Summer Paralympics medal table|medal table]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.paralympic.org/Athletes/Results |title=Atlanta 1996 Paralympic Games: Singapore |accessdate=2012-08-27 |work=paralympic.org}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.paralympic.org/results/historical|title=IPC Historical Results Archive (Paralympians search function, Country: Singapore, Competition: Atlanta 1996)|website=www.paralympic.org|accessdate=17 September 2016}} ==Disability classifications== {{main article|Disability sport classification}} Every participant at the Paralympics has their disability grouped into one of five [[Summer Paralympic Games#Disability categories|disability categories]]; [[amputation]], the condition may be congenital or sustained through injury or illness; [[cerebral palsy]]; [[wheelchair]] athletes, there is often overlap between this and other categories; [[visual impairment]], including [[blindness]]; Les autres, any physical disability that does not fall strictly under one of the other categories, for example [[dwarfism]] or [[multiple sclerosis]].{{cite web |title=Paralympics categories explained |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] |date=3 September 2008 |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/09/03/2354016.htm?site=paralympics/2008 |accessdate=25 December 2015}}{{cite news |title=Making sense of the categories |publisher=[[BBC|BBC Sport]] |date=6 October 2000 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics2000/paralympics/959701.stm |accessdate=25 December 2015}} Each [[Paralympic Games#Summer sports|Paralympic sport]] then has its own classifications, dependent upon the specific physical demands of competition. Events are given a code, made of numbers and letters, describing the type of event and classification of the athletes competing. Some sports, such as [[Athletics at the 2008 Summer Paralympics|athletics]], divide athletes by both the category and severity of their disabilities, other sports, for example [[Swimming at the 2008 Summer Paralympics|swimming]], group competitors from different categories together, the only separation being based on the severity of the disability.{{cite news |title=A-Z of Paralympic classification |publisher=[[BBC|BBC Sport]] |date=28 August 2008 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/disability_sport/7586684.stm |accessdate=25 December 2015}} ==Athletics== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; border: none;" !
