{{Infobox film | name = Southpaw | image = Southpaw poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Antoine Fuqua]] | producer = {{Plain list | * Todd Black * Jason Blumenthal * [[Steve Tisch]] * Peter Riche * Alan Riche * Antoine Fuqua * Jerry Ye }} | writer = [[Kurt Sutter]] | starring = {{Plain list | * [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] * [[Forest Whitaker]] * [[Naomie Harris]] * [[Curtis "50 Cent" Jackson]] * [[Oona Laurence]] * [[Rachel McAdams]] }} | music = [[James Horner]] | cinematography = [[Mauro Fiore]] | editing = [[John Refoua]] | studio = {{Plain list | * [[Wanda Media|Wanda Pictures]] * Riche Productions * [[Escape Artists]] * [[Antoine Fuqua|Fuqua Films]] }} | distributor = [[The Weinstein Company]] | released = {{Film date|2015|06|15|[[2015 Shanghai International Film Festival|SIFF]]|2015|07|24|United States}} | runtime = 123 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 123:32--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/southpaw-film | title=''SOUTHPAW'' (15) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=June 19, 2015 | accessdate=June 19, 2015}}</ref> | country = {{plainlist| * United States * China<ref name="Bloomberg">{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-07-23/hollywood-s-new-42-billion-man-marks-china-s-push-into-industry |title=China's Richest Man Marks Push Into Hollywood With Jake Gyllenhaal Movie |author=Sakoui, Anousha |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] |date=July 24, 2015 |accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> }} | language = English | budget = $30 million<ref name="AntMan2nd">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/07/pixels-paper-towns-southpaw-trainwreck-ant-man-box-office-1201484974/|title=‘Ant-Man’ Has Bragging Rights At The B.O. Over Adam Sandler’s ‘Pixels’ – Sunday AM Update|author=Anthony D'Alessandro|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=July 26, 2015|accessdate=July 26, 2015}}</ref> | gross = $92 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=southpaw2015.htm |title=Southpaw (2015) |website=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=June 16, 2016}}</ref> }}
'''''Southpaw''''' is a 2015 American [[Sports film|sports drama]] film directed by [[Antoine Fuqua]], written by [[Kurt Sutter]] and starring [[Jake Gyllenhaal]], [[Forest Whitaker]] and [[Rachel McAdams]]. The film follows a boxer who sets out to get his life back on track after losing his wife in an accident and his young daughter to protective services. The film was released on July 24, 2015, by [[The Weinstein Company]].
The film marked one of the last films to be scored by [[James Horner]], and one of three posthumous releases to feature his music. The film and the [[Southpaw (soundtrack)|film's soundtrack album]] are dedicated to his memory.
==Plot== Billy "The Great" Hope is an undefeated [[Professional boxing|professional boxer]] living in the suburbs of [[New York City]] with his wife Maureen and their daughter Leila. Billy's particular style of fighting often leaves him beaten and bruised. During a match in which he defends his [[light heavyweight]] world title, Billy sustains an eye injury as well as heavy blows to the face and body, leaving him coughing up blood for days. He is finally convinced by Maureen to retire before he becomes forever "punch-drunk". During the press conference at the post-match, an up-and-coming boxer Miguel "Magic" Escobar taunts Billy and tries to get Billy to fight him. At a charity event for the orphanage where he and his wife both grew up, Escobar is in attendance, and as Billy is leaving, Escobar threatens he'll take Maureen and his title away from him, and while Maureen tells Billy to let it go and go home with her, Billy's anger gets the best of him, leading to a brawl in which Maureen is accidentally shot and killed by Miguel's brother Hector, who flees.
Billy begins abusing alcohol and drugs while obsessively searching for Hector. He eventually gets a tip about Hector's whereabouts but only finds Hector's drug-addicted wife Maria, and leaves after learning Hector is a father. Billy attacks a referee out of frustration after throwing a fight and is suspended for a year, leaving him with no income and a six figure fine for ref assault. Furthermore, the networks are suing him for breach of contract, leaving him indebted and his house and belongings being repossessed. He continues to spiral out of control and nearly dies after crashing his car in a suicide attempt; he loses custody of Leila as a result, and she is put under care of [[Child Protective Services]] officer Angela Rivera. The incident drives Billy to sober up, but Leila cuts ties with him, blaming him for their predicament.
At the behest of his friends, Billy gets a job as a cleaner at a gym owned by seasoned boxer Titus "Tick" Wills, and tries to convince Tick to become his trainer. Billy's former manager, Jordan Mains, who is currently managing Miguel, arranges a fight between the two that could put Billy back in the spotlight. Tick is reluctant to train Billy, fearful he might be blinded by his vendetta against Miguel, but is motivated to do so when another of his students, Hoppy, is killed by his abusive father while attempting to defend his mother.
Seeing Billy's hard work after securing a job and keeping it, and his ability to show responsibilities of a father, a judge removes his visitation restrictions and congratulates him for his good work. Billy then takes Leila to his apartment where they have breakfast together and Leila asks if she can attend the fight. Billy, reluctant to let his daughter go to the fight because Maureen never wanted to expose their daughter to the violence in boxing, says he is unsure because Maureen used to make all the decisions for him. Leila asks if they can go visit Maureen's grave, where Leila convinces Billy to let her go to the fight to have someone by his side. Billy tells Leila that there will be people at the fight saying some harsh things, so Leila makes an agreement to go to the fight but stay only in the locker room with Angela, watching the fight via closed circuit television in the locker room.
As the match begins, Miguel has the upper hand against Billy, but, with Tick's advice, Billy has the chance to turn the tables in the final round by using the [[Boxing styles and technique#Defense|Philly shell defense]] and countering more aggressively with his left. As the round reaches its final minute, Billy pivots hard and, although fighting from a traditional stance, delivers a powerful left uppercut which knocks the champion down to the ground. Miguel manages to get up before the count is over and is saved by the bell. Billy is declared the winner by a split-decision and reunites with Leila in the locker room, where she forgives his past mistakes and they embrace.
==Cast== {{Div col}} * [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] as Billy "The Great" Hope<ref name="deadline1">{{cite web|last=Busch |first=Anita |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/03/antoine-fuqua-closes-deal-to-direct-southpaw-jake-gyllenhaal-set-to-star/ |title=Antoine Fuqua To Direct 'Southpaw' Movie Starring Jake Gyllenhaal |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2014-03-06 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> * [[Forest Whitaker]] as Titus "Tick" Wills<ref name="deadline2"/> * [[Rachel McAdams]] as Maureen Hope<ref name="deadline2">{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/05/twcs-southpaw-has-forest-whitaker-rachel-mcadams-and-lupita-nyongo-circling/ |title=Kurt Sutter's 'Southpaw' Movie Eyes Forest Whitaker, Rachel McAdams & Lupita Nyong'o |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2014-05-14 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> * [[Oona Laurence]] as Leila Hope<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwmovies/article/MATILDAs-Oona-Laurence-to-Star-in-Boxing-Drama-SOUTHPAW-20140619?PageSpeed=noscript |title=MATILDA's Oona Laurence to Star in Boxing Drama SOUTHPAW - BWWMoviesWorld |publisher=Broadwayworld.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> * [[Naomie Harris]] as Angela Rivera * [[Curtis "50 Cent" Jackson]] as Jordan Mains<ref>{{cite web|last=Smith |first=Emily |url=http://pagesix.com/2014/06/26/50-cent-joins-the-cast-of-jake-gyllenhaals-boxing-movie/ |title=50 Cent joins the cast of Jake Gyllenhaal’s boxing movie |publisher=Page Six |date=2014-06-26 |accessdate=2014-06-30}}</ref> * [[Miguel Gomez (actor)|Miguel Gomez]] as Miguel "Magic" Escobar<ref name="deadline4">{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/06/kaitlyn-dever-joins-the-greens-are-gone-miguel-gomez-cast-in-southpaw-richard-cabral-books-blood-father/ |title=Kaitlyn Dever Joins 'The Greens Are Gone'; Miguel Gomez Cast In 'Southpaw'; Richard Cabral Books 'Blood Father' |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2014-06-06 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> * Danny Henriquez as Hector Escobar * [[Rita Ora]] as Maria Escobar * [[Skylan Brooks]] as Hoppy * [[Victor Ortiz]] as Ramone<ref name="deadline3">{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/06/southpaw-adds-ex-champ-victor-ortiz-to-southpaw-cast/ |title='Southpaw' Adds Ex-Champ Victor Ortiz To Cast |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2014-06-17 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> * [[Beau Knapp]] as Jon Jon<ref name=Knapp>{{cite news|title=Beau Knapp Joins ‘Southpaw’|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/08/beau-knapp-southpaw-cullen-douglas-wrong-side-of-right/|accessdate=August 8, 2014|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=August 7, 2014}}</ref> * [[Malcolm Mays]] as Gabe * [[Clare Foley]] as Alice * [[Jim Lampley]] as himself * [[Roy Jones, Jr.]] as himself {{div col end}}
==Production== [[Eminem]] was originally supposed to play the role of Billy Hope. The film's screenwriter [[Kurt Sutter]] said the project was inspired by the rapper's personal struggles. He stated that he had taken meetings with Eminem's producing partners over the past seven years, looking for something to do together. "I know he's very selective and doesn't do a lot. But he shared so much of his personal struggle in this raw and very honest album, one that I connected with on a lot of levels. He is very interested in the boxing genre, and it seemed like an apt metaphor, because his own life has been a brawl. In a way, this is a continuation of the ''[[8 Mile (film)|8 Mile]]'' story, but we are doing a metaphorical narrative of the second chapter of his life. He'll play a world champion boxer who really hits a hard bottom, and has to fight to win back his life for his young daughter. At its core, this is a retelling of his struggles over the last five years of his life, using the boxing analogy. I love that the title refers to Marshall being a lefty, which is to boxing what a white rapper is to hip hop; dangerous, unwanted, and completely unorthodox. It's a much harder road for a [[southpaw]] than a right-handed boxer."<ref name="deadline5"/> Producers Alan and Peter Riche have given a slightly different story about Eminem's involvement however stating that they set out to make a boxing movie similar to ''[[The Champ (1931 film)|The Champ]]'' but wanted to make the story about a father-daughter relationship as opposed to ''The Champ''{{'}}s father-son story.<ref name="BI"/> Recalling Eminem's strong relationship with his daughter, they asked him and he was immediately receptive.<ref name="BI"/>
On December 13, 2010, [[DreamWorks]] acquired the script, with Eminem eyed to play the lead role,<ref name="deadline5">{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/12/dreamworks-teams-with-eminem-and-kurt-sutter-for-southpaw/ |title=DreamWorks Teams With Eminem And Kurt Sutter For 'Southpaw' |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2010-12-13 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> however the following August the studio dropped the project.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/08/eminem-antoine-fuqua-boxing-drama-southpaw-dropped-by-dreamworks-but-still-seeking-to-answer-bell/ |title=Eminem-Antoine Fuqua Boxing Drama 'Southpaw' Dropped By DreamWorks But Still Seeking To Answer Bell |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2011-08-11 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] picked up the film that October.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jeff Sneider |url=https://variety.com/2011/film/news/mgm-closes-eminem-pic-southpaw-1118044796/ |title=MGM closes Eminem pic ‘Southpaw’ |publisher=Variety |date=2011-10-20 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> in December 2012, Eminem dropped out of the film to focus instead on his music.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/eminems-second-movie-put-on-hold-20120510 |title=Eminem delays second movie, 'Southpaw' to focus on music. |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=2012-05-10 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> [[Antoine Fuqua]] signed on to the project in March 2014 with [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] replacing Eminem.<ref name="deadline1"/> Other casting news was announced in May 2014 with [[Forest Whitaker]], [[Lupita Nyong'o]], and [[Rachel McAdams]] officially joining the cast.<ref name="deadline2"/> In August of that year, it was announced that [[Naomie Harris]] would be replacing Nyong'o.<ref name="deadline6">{{cite web|last=Yamato |first=Jen |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/08/naomie-harris-jake-gyllenhaal-southpaw/ |title=Naomie Harris Joins Jake Gyllenhaal In 'Southpaw' |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref>
Gyllenhaal did research for his role by doing "tons of reading on boxers, orphan boxers, the spirit of gyms all over America, children who start early, [and] the history of [[foster care]] in America"<ref name="huffington research"/> while also spending five months training as a boxer.<ref name="huffington research">{{cite web|last1=Jacobs|first1=Matthew|title=With ‘Southpaw,’ Jake Gyllenhaal’s Physical Transformations Become A One-Two Punch|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/jake-gyllenhaal-southpaw_us_55ae83dde4b07af29d567e26|website=Huffington Post|accessdate=28 March 2016}}</ref> Eminem would later praise Gyllenhaal's performance, noting that "Jake smashed it" in an interview with [[Zane Lowe]].<ref name="BI">{{cite web|last1=Guerrasio|first1=Jason|title=New movie 'Southpaw' was created for Eminem — but here's why the role ended up going to Jake Gyllenhaal|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/southpaw-eminem-jake-gyllenhaal-casting-2015-7|website=Business Insider|accessdate=28 March 2016}}</ref>
''Southpaw'' marks the first investment in an American film by Wanda Pictures, a division of [[Wang Jianlin]]'s Chinese conglomerate [[Dalian Wanda Group]].<ref name="Bloomberg"/> [[Principal photography]] began on June 16, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.studiosystemnews.com/on-the-set-for-61614-boxing-drama-southpaw-starts-american-ultra-wraps/ |title=On The Set For 6/16/14: Boxing Drama ‘Southpaw’ Starts, ‘American Ultra’ Wraps |publisher=Studiosystemnews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> Filming took place in [[Pittsburgh]] and [[Indiana, Pennsylvania]], and sets in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtae.com/entertainment/extras-needed-for-new-jake-gyllenhaal-movie-to-film-in-pittsburgh-area/26097472#!bC316x|title='Southpaw' movie now filming in Downtown Pittsburgh|work=wtae|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/movies/2014/08/17/City-native-Antoine-Fuqua-filmed-his-movie-here/stories/201408170027|title=Pittsburgh native Antoine Fuqua returns to direct 'Southpaw'|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|accessdate=23 October 2014|date=2014-08-17}}</ref>
==Release== The film had its world premiere at the [[2015 Shanghai International Film Festival]] on June 15, 2015, where it was in competition,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.filmbiz.asia/news/shanghai-completes-competition-lineup|title= Shanghai completes competition lineup|author= Kevin Ma|date= June 4, 2015|accessdate= June 4, 2015|work= [[Film Business Asia]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150611191956/http://www.filmbiz.asia/news/shanghai-completes-competition-lineup|archivedate= June 11, 2015|df= }}</ref> and was released on July 24, 2015, by [[The Weinstein Company]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/southpaw-release-date-july-31-2015/|title=Southpaw Set for July 31st Release; Sacha Baron Cohen Comedy Pushed to 2016|work=Collider|accessdate=21 January 2015}}</ref>
==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Southpaw'' grossed $52.4 million in North America and $38.5 million in other territories for a total gross of $92 million, against a budget of $25 million.<ref name="BOM"/>
In its opening weekend, the film grossed $16.7 million from 2,772 theaters, finishing 5th at the box office.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-pixels-paper-towns-811139|title=Box Office: 'Pixels,' 'Paper Towns' Stall; 'Southpaw' Overperforms|author=Pamela McClintock|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=July 26, 2015|accessdate=July 26, 2015}}</ref>
===Critical response=== The [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film a rating of 60%, based on 222 reviews, with a [[Weighted arithmetic mean|rating average]] of 6/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Jake Gyllenhaal delivers an impressively committed performance, but ''Southpaw'' beats it down with a dispiriting drama that pummels viewers with genre clichés."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/southpaw_2015/|title=Southpaw|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Flixster]]|accessdate=February 14, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 57 out of 100, based on 42 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/southpaw-2015 | title=Southpaw | work=[[Metacritic]] | publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] | accessdate=July 26, 2015}}</ref> On [[CinemaScore]], audiences gave the film an average grade of "A" on an A+ to F scale.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/07/pixels-paper-towns-southpaw-trainwreck-ant-man-box-office-1201484974/|title=‘Ant-Man’ Has Bragging Rights At The B.O. Over Adam Sandler’s ‘Pixels’ – Sunday AM Update|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|date=26 July 2015|website=Deadline Hollywood}}</ref>
Soren Anderson of ''[[The Seattle Times]]'' gave the film two and a half stars out of four, saying "''Southpaw'', a boxing movie with a theme of redemption, is redeemed by the performances of its two main actors, Jake Gyllenhaal and Forest Whitaker."<ref>{{cite web|last=Andersen |first=Soren |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/movies/southpaw-hokey-boxing-film-has-fine-acting-in-its-corner/ |title=‘Southpaw’: Hokey boxing film has fine acting in its corner |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Kyle Smith of the ''[[New York Post]]'' gave the film one and a half stars out of four, saying "It brings back every stale genre convention you can think of, then hopes you won't recognize predictability pumped up with swearing and steroids and an Eminem song during the training montage."<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith |first=Kyle |url=https://nypost.com/2015/07/23/jake-gyllenhaals-southpaw-is-a-stale-cliche-filled-fight/ |title=Jake Gyllenhaal’s ‘Southpaw’ is a stale, cliche-filled fight | New York Post |publisher=Nypost.com |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Ty Burr of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' gave the film two and a half stars out of four, saying "This is a genre with especially sturdy bones, and when ''Southpaw'' connects, which is more often than you might expect, you feel it down to your toes."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/movies/2015/07/23/southpaw-old-two-punch/5bdZfJeFAj1kzPAgtdiVeO/story.html |title=In ‘Southpaw,’ it’s the old 0ne-two punch - Movies |publisher=The Boston Globe |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Ann Hornaday of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' gave the film one and a half stars out of four, saying "''Southpaw'' may be rote, predictable and mawkish, but none of those faults lie in its star. Even when he looks like an unholy mess, he transcends the movie he's in."<ref>{{cite news|last=Hornaday |first=Ann |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/jake-gyllenhaal-transforms-in-the-boxing-drama-southpaw/2015/07/22/ce0aa0fe-2fcb-11e5-8353-1215475949f4_story.html |title=Jake Gyllenhaal transforms in the boxing drama ‘Southpaw’ |publisher=The Washington Post |date= 2015-07-23|accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Steven Rea of ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "What keeps this cornball business from getting out of hand is the commitment of Gyllenhaal, whose performance is fierce and muscular, in and out of the ring."<ref>{{cite web|author=Steven Rea, Inquirer Movie Columnist and Critic |url=http://www.philly.com/philly/entertainment/movies/20150724__Southpaw___Boxing_s_life_lessons.html |title='Southpaw': Boxing's life lessons |publisher=Philly.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Michael Phillips of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' gave the film two and a half stars out of four, saying "The script may have hamburger for brains, but Fuqua slams it home with the help of actors who give their all - even when giving a little less might have made things more interesting."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/movies/ct-southpaw-movie-review-jake-gyllenhaal-20150723-column.html#navtype=barker&barkername=Barker%2006%20-%20In%20Case%20You%20Missed%20It |title='Southpaw' movie review: Jake Gyllenhaal fights through tragedy |publisher=Chicago Tribune |date= 2015-07-23|accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref>
Peter Howell of the ''[[Toronto Star]]'' gave the film two and a half stars out of four, saying "This isn't great cinema, but it's satisfying movie-making, with nothing more on its mind than telling a heart-tugging story."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/movies/2015/07/23/faces-punched-hearts-tugged-southpaw-review.html |title=Faces punched, hearts tugged: Southpaw review | Toronto Star |publisher=Thestar.com |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> [[A. O. Scott]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' said, "I wish I could say ''Southpaw'' was a knockout, or even a contender, that it went the distance or scored on points. But it's strictly an undercard bout, displaying enough heart and skill to keep the paying customers from getting too restless."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/24/movies/review-in-southpaw-jake-gyllenhaal-tries-to-box-his-way-back-from-tragedy.html?partner=rss&emc=rss&_r=0 |title=Review: In ‘Southpaw,’ Jake Gyllenhaal Tries to Box His Way Back From Tragedy |publisher=The New York Times |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31 |first=A. O. |last=Scott}}</ref> Benjamin Nugent of ''The New York Times'' has compared the film to Robert De Niro stating, "Pity Jake Gyllenhaal, who despite getting shredded for ''Southpaw'', could not outbox the shadow of Robert De Niro's ''Raging Bull'' performance."<ref>Nugent, Benjamin [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/02/t-magazine/boxing-films.html The Ring Cycle: Boxing’s Eternal Cinematic Appeal] ''New York Times''. September 3, 2015</ref> Chris Nashawaty of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the film a C+, saying "Just as director Antoine Fuqua starts to close in on something interesting and unexpected, he retreats to the safety of his corner and gives us what we've seen too many times before: a predictable flurry of melodramatic jabs."<ref>{{cite news|last=Nashawaty |first=Chris |url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/07/23/southpaw-ew-review |title='Southpaw': EW review |publisher=EW.com |date= 2015-07-22|accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Barbara VanDenburgh of ''[[The Arizona Republic]]'' gave the film three out of five stars, saying "''Southpaw'' is all about the fist. There's no delicate footwork here, no lingering grace notes. It's a film played entirely in power chords."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/movies/2015/07/23/review-southpaw-packs-little-punch/30434849/ |title=Review: ‘Southpaw’ packs too little punch |publisher=Azcentral.com |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> [[James Berardinelli]] of ''[[ReelViews]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "''Southpaw'' isn't content with presenting a gallery of clichéd characters. It takes the time to put flesh on the bones."<ref>{{cite web|author=James Berardinelli |url=http://www.reelviews.net/reelviews/southpaw |title=Southpaw | Reelviews Movie Reviews |publisher=Reelviews.net |date=2015-07-25 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Colin Covert of the ''[[Star Tribune]]'' gave the film one out of four stars, slamming Gyllenhaal's performance, saying "As a troubled slugger, Gyllenhaal is impressively muscle-bound, but gives no knockout performance. His work drags on like 12 rounds of fistfight fatigue."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/review-southpaw-gets-ko-d-quick-thanks-to-a-miscast-jake-gyllenhaal/318307301/ |title='Southpaw' gets KO'd quick, thanks to a miscast Jake Gyllenhaal |publisher=StarTribune.com |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref>
===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Award ! Category ! Recipient ! Result ! {{Abbr|Ref.|References}} |- | rowspan="2"|[[Black Reel Awards of 2016|Black Reel Awards]] | Best Director | [[Antoine Fuqua]] | {{nominated}} | rowspan=2| <ref>{{cite web |url=http://blackreelawards.com/black-reel-awards-16-winners-nominees/ |title=Black Reel Awards '16 |year=2016 |access-date=22 May 2018 |work=[[Black Reel Awards]]}}</ref> |- | Best Supporting Actor | [[Forest Whitaker]] | {{nominated}} |- | [[Jupiter Award (film award)|Jupiter Award]] | Best International Actor | [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] | {{nom}} | |- | [[Motion Picture Sound Editors|Golden Reel Awards]] | Sound Effects and Foley in a Feature Film | | {{nom}} | |- | [[NAACP Image Award]]s | [[NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture|Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture]] | Forest Whitaker | {{nom}} | |- | [[Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association]] | Best Youth Performance | [[Oona Laurence]] | {{nom}} | |}
==Soundtrack== {{main|Southpaw (soundtrack)}} [[Eminem]] executive-produced the soundtrack, which was released by [[Shady Records]] on July 24, 2015. He had previously released his single called "[[Phenomenal (song)|Phenomenal]]" from the soundtrack on June 2, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/eminem/85642|title=NME News Eminem to release new song on 'Southpaw' soundtrack - NME.COM|author=Rhian Daly|date=23 May 2015|work=NME.COM}}</ref>
An album of [[James Horner]]'s score was released through [[Sony Classical]] on July 24, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2015/06/02/southpaw-score-album-details/|title='Southpaw' Score Album Details - Film Music Reporter|date=June 2, 2015|work=Film Music Reporter}}</ref> This was Horner's final score (it was recorded after ''[[The 33 (film)|The 33]]'', although ''Southpaw'' was released first); he was killed in a plane crash on June 22, 2015.<ref name="CBCobit">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/pilot-dies-in-plane-registered-to-james-horner-titanic-composer-1.3123768 |title=Pilot dies in plane registered to James Horner, Titanic composer |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=June 22, 2015 |accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox clothing item | image_file = Eben Etzebeth.jpg | image_size = 100px | caption = [[Eben Etzebeth]] in Springbok colours | designer = Paul Rose | year = 1906 | type = blazer | material = | on_display_at = }} '''Springbok colours''' is the name given to green and gold blazers awarded to members of the [[South Africa national rugby union team]]. They were historically awarded to teams and individuals representing [[South Africa]] in international competition of any sport, following their creation in 1906. With the arrival of South Africa's new post-apartheid government in 1994, the name ''Springbok'' was abandoned by the various control boards since they felt that the term had been abused by the previous [[apartheid]] governments, and stigmatised by the anti-apartheid movement.<ref name=bok /> An exception was made in the case of the national rugby union team, who have retained the practice of awarding colours.
== History == The first Springbok colours were created in 1906 during the [[1906–07 South Africa rugby union tour]] of the Northern Hemisphere as none had been provided for them and the captain [[Paul Roos (rugby player)|Paul Roos]] decided that the team need to create their own emblem and nickname to prevent the British press creating one for them. Using the guidelines that the director of the [[South African Rugby Board]] (SARB) had given for the playing kit of myrtle green jerseys and a gold collar, Roos instructed that a green blazer with gold [[Piping (sewing)|piping]] and a Springbok emblem on the breast pocket would be made for the team in [[Richmond, London|Richmond]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rugbyfootballhistory.com/south_africa.html |title=South Africa |publisher=Rugby Football History |date= |accessdate=2016-08-11}}</ref> Despite this, not many colours were made as they were not standard issue at the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/shropshire/3691122.stm |title=Rare rugby blazer put up for sale |publisher=BBC News |date=2004-09-26 |accessdate=2016-05-11}}</ref> Later on they became standard issue for all sportsmen representing South Africa internationally but primarily was used by rugby union as the creators.<ref name=rr />
[[File:1937 span 011.jpg|thumb|right|150px|The South Africa rugby union team wearing Springbok colours in 1937]] The first dispute over Springbok colours came from the rise of [[rugby league in South Africa]] in the 1950s. SARB felt it was their duty as members of the [[World Rugby|International Rugby Football Board]] to defend amateur rugby union against professional rugby league after several Springboks had defected to rugby league.<ref name=thir /> In 1959, the SARB declared that all players that represented South Africa in rugby union had to sign a declaration they would not turn professional for two years. Any player who refused this was obliged to return his Springbok colours and was not permitted to purchase a replacement.<ref name=thir>Conellisen, 13</ref>
In 1963, the SARB took the step of copyrighting the Springbok emblem and Springbok colours as a badge under the [[Heraldry Act]]<ref name=cr>{{cite journal|url=http://blogs.sun.ac.za/iplaw/files/2011/12/SPORT-AS-A-BRAND-AND-ITS-LEGAL-PROTECTION-IN-SOUTH-AFRICA.pdf |title=Sport as a brand and its legal protection in South Africa |publisher=Stellenbosch University |date= |accessdate=2016-05-11}}</ref> to pre-empt any other sporting body copyrighting it. The board initially declared, it was happy to share the Springbok colours providing that they were only awarded to white amateur sportspeople representing South Africa internationally.<ref name=sarb>Conellisen, 18–19</ref> It was also an attempt to try and stop the [[South Africa national rugby league team]] from using the colours, though [[South African Rugby League|Rugby League South Africa]] circumvented this by developing their own version of the Springbok colours.<ref name=sarb /> Later legislation in 1971 was passed in order to enforce [[apartheid]] so that only white South Africans could be awarded Springbok colours<ref name=bok>{{cite web|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-187035625.html |title=The time when it was right to ban the Springbok has long passed |work=The Mercury |date= |accessdate=2016-05-11}} {{Subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> though this later extended to those deemed as "[[honorary whites]]".<ref name=Chinese /> This came after three black Africans were awarded Springbok colours for competing in the World Paraplegic Games. Later as a result of the legislation, Glen Popham was not awarded Springbok colours following winning a gold medal in [[Karate]] in the 1969 [[South African Games]] alongside his white team, as his race was officially classified as [[Coloured]] which the [[South African Sports Confederation and Olympic Committee|South African National Olympic Committee]] were not aware of prior.<ref name=rr>{{cite book | first=Muriel |last=Horell | title =A Survey of Race Relations in South Africa |publisher = University of California Press | edition = | year = 1972 | isbn = 0869820109 |page=316}}</ref> As non-whites were not eligible to be selected for South African national sports teams, the Springbok colours came to be viewed as a symbol of white supremacy in apartheid South Africa because they were only awarded to white sportspeople.<ref>{{cite book | first=Maurice |last=Hommel | title =Conversations and Soliloquies: A Window on South Africa |publisher = iUniverse | edition = | year = 2012 | isbn = 1462084079 |page=142}}</ref>
== Post apartheid == Following the repeal of apartheid legislation, Springbok colours started to be issued to non-whites.<ref name=Chinese>{{cite book | first =Melanie| last =Yap | title =Colour, Confusion and Concessions: The History of the Chinese in South Africa | publisher = Hong Kong University Press | edition = | year = 1996 | isbn = 9622094244 | page = 394}}</ref> In 1994, following the election of [[Nelson Mandela]] and the [[African National Congress]], the National Colours Board was set up to control the distribution of Springbok colours.<ref name=cr /> Despite this, the majority of South Africa's sporting organisations stopped awarding Springbok colours, following the replacement of the Springbok by the [[Protea]] by government demand. The only sporting body in South Africa that was allowed to retain Springbok colours was the [[South African Rugby Union]] as an act of conciliation towards the white minority who made up the majority of the national rugby union team.<ref name=bok />
In 2008, the South African Sports Minister claimed under the National Sport and Recreation Act, 1998, that the Springbok colours copyright had been transferred to the government and the SARU had been issuing it illegally and requested they cease using it. However, legal writers stated that the South African government's claim had expired in 2007 while SARU's copyright still was valid and pursuant to the case of ''In re: Certification of the Constitution of the RSA 1996'', if the government tried to stop the SARU issuing Springbok colours, then the government would be liable to pay millions of [[South African Rand|Rands]] in compensation.<ref name=cr /> In 2013, as part of their "Yesterday's Heroes" programme, SARU retrospectively awarded Springbok colours to all non-whites who had played for a South African national team such as the black [[SAARB Leopards (rugby team)|SAARB Leopards]] and the Coloured [[Proteas (rugby union)|Proteas]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/local-news/goolams-long-wait-finally-over-1134437 |title=Goolam's long wait finally over |work=Manchester Evening News |date= |accessdate=2016-05-12}}</ref>
Springbok colours are only awarded to South Africans. Australian [[Eddie Jones (rugby union)|Eddie Jones]], who worked as a technical advisor to South Africa for the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]], was not allowed Springbok colours as a non-South African<ref>{{cite web|last=Keohane |first=Mark |url=http://www.iol.co.za/sport/thanks-eddie-but-you-dont-get-a-bok-blazer-577774 |title=Thanks Eddie, but you don't get a Bok blazer |publisher=IOL |date=2007-09-07 |accessdate=2016-05-11}}</ref> and was obliged to wear a South Africa tracksuit when pitchside.<ref>{{cite web|last=Woolford |first=Anthony |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/rugby/rugby-news/who-eddie-jones-how-good-10467741 |title=Who is Eddie Jones? How good is he? What you need to know about the man set to be named England coach |publisher=Wales Online |date=2015-11-19 |accessdate=2016-05-11}}</ref> Following South Africa's victory that year, all other players and coaching team members were expected to wear their Springbok colours to the post-tournament awards dinner. In protest at Jones not being issued with colours, [[Bryan Habana]] gave his to Jones and the team attended the awards dinner in suits instead.<ref>{{cite web|last=Henson |first=Mike |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/rugby-union/35478033 |title=Eddie Jones: Meet England's new coach for Six Nations 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2016-02-04 |accessdate=2016-05-11}}</ref>

Türk Telekom Stadı | former_names = Türk Telekom Arena (2011–2017) | location = [[Sarıyer]], [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] | coordinates = {{coord|41|6|10.33|N|28|59|25.51|E|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 13 December 2007 | home team = [[Galatasaray S.K.]] | built = 2007–2011 | opened = {{Start date and years ago|2011|1|15|df=yes}} | owner = [[Galatasaray SK]] | operator = [[Galatasaray SK]] | tenant = [[Galatasaray S.K. (football)|Galatasaray SK]] (2011–present) | surface = [[Grass]] (2011–2018)
[[Hybrid grass|SISGrass]] | scoreboard = 2 x 77,41m²{{cite web |url=http://www.glass-screen.net/uygulamalar.asp?ID%3D24 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141011192349/http://www.glass-screen.net/uygulamalar.asp?ID=24 |archivedate=2014-10-11 |df= }} | construction_cost =[[United States dollar|$]]250 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|250000000|2011}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}){{cite web|url=http://www.objektifhaber.com/Ekonomi/36801-Ali-Sami-Yen-icin-461-milyon-TL-.html |title=Ali Sami Yen'de son teklifler alındı – 28 Mayıs 2010, Cuma |website=Objektifhaber.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08}}{{cite web|url=http://www.finansgundem.com/haber/oku/gundem/27028/ali_sami_yenin_sahibi_kim_oldu/print/print |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711002319/http://www.finansgundem.com/haber/oku/gundem/27028/ali_sami_yenin_sahibi_kim_oldu/print/print |archivedate=2011-07-11 |df= }} | architect = 'asp' architekten Stuttgart{{cite web|url=http://www.asp-stuttgart.de/ |title='asp' Architekten Arat – Schust, Stuttgart |website=Asp-stuttgart.de |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08}} | project_manager = | structural engineer = İz Mühendislik
Yüksel Proje
[[Schlaich Bergermann & Partner]]{{cite web|url=http://v2.arkiv.com.tr/p11020-turk-telekom-arena.html |title=Türk Telekom Arena |website=V2.arkiv.com.tr |date=2012-05-15 |accessdate=2016-08-08}} | services engineer = OBERMEYER: Planungsgesellschaft{{cite web|url=http://www.opb.de/ |title=OBERMEYER: Planungsgesellschaft |website=Opb.de |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08}} | general_contractor = | main_contractors = Varyap-Uzunlar | seating_capacity = 52,652 (2011–2013)
52,223 ([[all-seater stadium|all-seater]])http://www.tff.org/Default.aspx?pageID=394&stadID=5018
| dimensions = {{convert|105|x|68|m|yd|abbr=on}} | Suites = 198{{cite web|author=Ali Naci |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/spor/futbol/20817055.asp |title=Rekor ve gurur – Futbol Haberleri |website=Hurriyet.com.tr |date=2012-06-22 |accessdate=2016-08-08}} | record_attendance = {{formatnum: 52044}} ([[Galatasaray SK|Galatasaray]]-[[Real Madrid CF|Real Madrid]], 9 April 2013) | acreage = 40,000 m² | volume = 190,000m² |publictransit = {{rint|Istanbul|metro}} [[Seyrantepe (Istanbul Metro)|Seyrantepe]]
{{rint|istanbul|f3}} [[Seyrantepe (Istanbul Metro)|Seyrantepe]] | website = {{URL|http://www.turktelekomarena.com.tr}} }} Officially '''Ali Sami Yen Spor Kompleksi – Türk Telekom Stadium''', is a [[association football|football]] stadium serving as the home ground of the [[Süper Lig]] club [[Galatasaray S.K.]]. It is located in the Seyrantepe quarter of the [[Sarıyer]] district{{Cite news|url=http://www.turktelekomstadyumu.com/konum|title=Türk Telekom Stadyumu|last=Telekom|first=Türk|access-date=2018-03-14}}, on the European side of [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]]. The [[all-seater stadium]] has the capacity to host 52,223http://www.tff.org/Default.aspx?pageID=394&stadID=5018 spectators during football games. Türk Telekom Stadium was the first stadium in Turkey that met the [[UEFA Euro 2016]] requirements during the country's bid to host the [[UEFA European Football Championship|European Championship]].{{cite web |url=http://www.xn--fotoma-1ua.com.tr/Galatasaray/2011/05/05/uefa-kriterlerine-uyan-tek-stat |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110508142427/http://www.xn--fotoma-1ua.com.tr/Galatasaray/2011/05/05/uefa-kriterlerine-uyan-tek-stat |archivedate=2011-05-08 |df= }} In 2011, Türk Telekom Stadium was one of the six nominees for the ''Venue of the Year'' and ''New Venue'' categories of the [[Stadium Business Awards]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20110521093110/http://www.stadiumbusinessawards.com/shortlist-announced-for-stadium-business-awards-2011/] Galatasaray SK won the [[2011–12 Süper Lig|Süper Lig]] in the first season at Türk Telekom Stadium. Türk Telekom Stadium and Galatasaray SK were mentioned in the first chapter of [[Tom Clancy]]'s 2012 novel ''[[Threat Vector]]''.{{cite book|last=Clancy|first=Tom|title=Threat Vector|year=2012|publisher=Putnam Adult|location=USA|isbn=0399160450|page=|pages=15, 18|url=https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0399160450#reader_0399160450}} ==History== [[File:Galatasaray Arena South-East Corner.jpg|thumb|View of the stadium from the southeast stand corner, June 2017]] Football (soccer) was first played in Istanbul by some British players in a field known as [[Papazın Çayırı]] ("Priest’s Field") in the area that is now the site of [[Fenerbahçe]]'s [[Şükrü Saracoğlu Stadium]]. With the opening of the [[Taksim Stadium]] in 1921, it was this new stadium that became the new football headquarters. In the urban development of 1939, the military barracks in which the Taksim Stadium was located was demolished in 1940. The stadium was thus lost. In this period, Fenerbahçe bought the land encompassing Papazın Çayırı and built the Fenerbahçe Stadium, while the Beşiktaş Club moved into the [[Şeref Stadium]], located in the area where today’s [[Çırağan Palace|Çırağan Palace Hotel]] stands. It was Galatasaray that experienced the biggest problem with the use of a stadium in that period. The first steps to overcome this problem were taken in the initial years of the 1930s. The first initiative to acquire a plot of land for Galatasaray was in 1933, when the then president of the club Ali Haydar Barşal showed an interest in a mulberry orchard in [[Mecidiyeköy]]. In the period between 1933 and 1935, negotiations with the government resulted in the allocation of a plot of land outside of the city limits in Mecidiye Köyü (Mecidiye Village, present-day Mecidiyeköy quarter of the [[Şişli]] district) for a stadium to be built for Galatasaray. Excavations for the construction began in 1936. The President of the Turkish Sports Organization at the time, Adnan Menderes, provided financial assistance for the project. However, the efforts were left in the excavation stage. In 1940, the matter of the stadium came up again under the presidency of Tevfik Ali Çınar. The same plot of land was leased to Galatasaray for a term of 30 years at a symbolic yearly rental fee of 1 lira. Galatasaray thus acquired the right to the use of the land. In leasing the land, Galatasaray committed to building a modern stadium as well as a bicycle velodrome. The construction could not start, however, due to limited funds and the general atmosphere of the war years. In 1943, Osman Dardağan led an initiative to build a modest stadium that would answer the immediate need. In the atmosphere of war, only a small open tribune was allowed in the stadium, which was set on a field of earth and inaugurated under the presidency of Muslihittin Peykoğlu in 1945. However, its distance from the city center in those days, its inaccessibility by public transportation, and the rough winds that characterized the district were factors that contributed to a long period in which the stadium would lay idle and football games never took place. When the [[İnönü Stadium]] in the center of the city was opened in that period, Galatasaray abandoned the stadium building project in Mecidiyeköy, putting the project aside before fruition. In 1955, 30 more years were added to the right of utilization agreement, which at the time had 22 years to go, extending the terms until 2007. When the Club failed to undertake the building of the Stadium, the project was taken on by the Physical Education General Directorate. The construction started in 1959. In 1961, during the presidency of Refik Selimoğlu, a new agreement was signed with the Physical Education General Directorate whereby the utilization rights of the newly completed stadium were explicitly given to Galatasaray. The stadium was opened on an eventful December 20, 1964. In the midst of the extreme crowds present, panic broke out, resulting in the death of one spectator and the injury of 80 others. In 1965, the stadium was illuminated for the first time. Despite this, however, not many night games were played. At the beginning of the 1970s, the stadium was abandoned for another period during which the İnönü Stadium began to be used again. In the 1970s, the stadium was mostly used by Galatasaray for training sessions. In those years, it remained in a squalid state of neglect. In 1981, grass was planted on the field and the stadium was opened again. The lighting system was renewed in 1993, after which night games began to be played once more. In the same year, the system of combined tickets was initiated in Turkey at the [[Ali Sami Yen Stadium]]. Also in the same year, the stadium was furnished with seats to replace the old benches. The capacity of the stadium was thus reduced from 35,000 to an all-seater capacity of 22,000. In 1997, the Galatasaray administration assigned a Canadian architectural firm for the task of designing Turkey's first multi-function, modern stadium to be built in place of the [[Ali Sami Yen Stadium]], which was planned to be torn down. On 10 December 2013, a [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] match between Galatasaray and [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] had to be abandoned due to heavy snow in the 32nd minute with the score 0–0, the remaining minutes of the match were played the next day.{{cite web|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2521580/Galatasarays-game-Juventus-abandoned-extreme-weather.html|title= Galatasaray's crunch clash with Juventus abandoned due to extreme weather|date=10 December 2013|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=11 December 2013}} ===New stadium projects=== ====Faruk Süren project==== The new stadium project was launched in 1998 and it attracted wide interest. During the promotion of the modern loge system, the entire loge section was sold at a symbolical fee. The proposed capacity was 40,484. However, the mayor and the state did not allow of a stadium to be built. ====Mehmet Cansun project==== Over the period of 2001–2002, a revision was made in the project with an eye toward reducing the amount needed for financing but this time, although costs were brought down, the economic crisis of 2001 stood in the way of overcoming the financial issue. Capacity was reduced to 35,000. ====Özhan Canaydın: Back to Süren's project==== In the 2002–04 season, the old project came up again but was abandoned in favor of building a new and modern stadium. Again, financing needs could not be met. After a general renovation that took place in the 2004–05 season, the club returned to the [[Ali Sami Yen Stadium]]. Following the [[1999 İzmit earthquake]], the old Open Tribune was demolished and replaced in the 2005–2006 season for safety reasons. ====Özhan Canaydın: Leaving Mecidiyeköy, new home in Aslantepe==== Because Mecidiyeköy was now a part of the city center, state authorities objected to the expansion of the stadium in this district. A new piece of land was suggested to Galatasaray as an alternative. The search for financing for the new stadium that would be built on this new plot continued over the period of 2004–07. In 2007, discussions with state authorities regarding the erection of a new Galatasaray stadium in Aslantepe yielded positive results. It was decided that the new stadium would be built within two years on the new land plot that would be transferred to Galatasaray, in exchange for the club's property in Mecidiyeköy on which the [[Ali Sami Yen Stadium]] stood. ====A dream comes true==== [[File:Galatasaray Arena North-East Corner.jpg|thumb|View of the stadium from the northeast stand corner, June 2017]] At the end of 2007, ten years after the initial announcement of the project in 1997, the groundbreaking for the new stadium was carried out (December 13, 2007) at a ceremony attended by state officials. The old project was put aside and a new project was contracted to Mete Arat in Germany. 2008, In Galatasaray’s last year at the [[Ali Sami Yen Stadium]], the Lower Closed Tribune was renovated in line with UEFA standards. 2009, The construction of the new stadium, the Türk Telekom Stadium, gained speed when the contracting company was changed. 2010, It was announced that the official opening of the new stadium would take place on January 15, 2011, with Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] presiding. But in the opening ceremony, he was protested by spectators of Galatasaray. ====Project overview==== {|class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%; margin:0" |- ! Project ! Year ! Location ! (${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|250000000|2011}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) |'''Built''' |} == Aslantepe == [[File:Ali Sami Yen Spor Kompleksi Türk Telekom Arena6.jpg|thumb|300px|Exterior view]] In recent years, numerous proposals had been put forward to demolish the current stadium and build a new, larger one on the same location, but this was impossible due to the lack of space. Finally, the club's stadium, [[Ali Sami Yen Stadium]], was now going to be replaced with a new stadium near [[Maslak]] financial district. The former name of the district, ''Seyrantepe'', was changed to ''Aslantepe'' (Lion Hill) after [[Galatasaray S.K.|Galatasaray]] purchased the land; ''Aslan'' ("Lion") being Galatasaray's symbol. The idea was to realize a stadium on the model of [[Arena AufSchalke]] in Gelsenkirchen, Germany. The stadium will feature a world-class retractable roof—the first of its kind in Turkey. The design team headed by 'asp' Architekten Stuttgart combines the engineering expertise of the renowned firms Obermeyer Planen+Beraten (Munich), Schlaich – Bergermann and Partner (Stuttgart) and Yüksel Proje (Ankara). === Auction process === Galatasaray have been in cooperation with TOKİ (one of the biggest construction organizations of Turkey, budgeted by the Turkish government). Among the four companies that tendered proposals, the best offer was put forward by the Eren Talu Architecture – ALKE Partnership. The contract for the tender held for the construction of Galatasaray's new stadium was signed between TOKİ and Eren Talu-ALKE consortium on 23 October 2007.[http://www.galatasaray.org/english/detail.asp?PID=1160&HID=2&haberID=301015] {{dead link|date=August 2016}} The contract of the tender was realized by TOKİ and came to be known as the "Aslantepe Tender", covering the construction of a multi-purpose sports complex with 52,652 spectator capacity on Aslantepe (formerly known as Seyrantepe) premises in return for building "Urban Social Infrastructure Areas" on 34.640 sq meters of land on which the present Ali Sami Yen Stadium is located. There is a set period of 720 days for the construction of the stadium that will be built on the Aslantepe (formerly known as Seyrantepe) premises. The box count is 198 Part of the catering areas Turk Telekom Stadium consists of, is a VIP lounge room, VIP Market Area, Premium Food Court, Galatasaray Museum, Galatasaray Mega Store, 11 Galatasaray Store and a VIP restaurant. The modern stadium, contains five top and four underground levels.{{cite web |url=http://www.turktelekomarena.com.tr/stad-bilgileri |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111104060207/http://www.turktelekomarena.com.tr/stad-bilgileri |archivedate=2011-11-04 |df= }} === Partnership === Once the Eren Talu-ALKE consortium had won the tender for the stadium project, they proceeded to find a foreign technical partner with previous experience in sports-construction related projects. They were introduced to the Abu Dhabi Group and Al Zarooni Group, both headquartered in the UAE. Abu Dhabi Group (also known as Dhabi Group), the largest foreign investor group in Pakistan, and the Al Zarooni Group are investors in the gigantic 5.5 million sq.m. [[Dubai Sports City]] project that is currently under construction in Dubai. The Chairman of Abu Dhabi Group is His Highness [[Sheikh Nahayan Mabarak Al Nahayan]], who is also the Federal Minister for Higher Education & Scientific Research of the UAE and a very important member of Abu Dhabi's Ruling Family. The Dhabi-Zarooni consortium acquired 51% of the Eren Talu-ALKE consortium’s shares to co-invest a total of $650 million with them in the Aslantepe (New Stadium) and [[Mecidiyeköy]] (Old Stadium) projects. Stating that a total amount of $650 million will be invested for the entire project, Eren Talu said, "$170 million of this amount will be spent for the stadium, in addition to $180 million which is the guaranteed TOKİ share, a $50 million additional TOKİ share and the remaining $250 million+ to be invested in the [[mixed-use development]] project intended in Mecidiyeköy". Talu added that TOKİ's participation in the project provides great advantage for the partnership and continued, “our partners had confidence in the public benefit of the project and decided to join within a short period of just 2 months". Talu said they have already spent $37 million so far in order to construct up to the current level of the stadium. Stating that the stadium is to be delivered on time on 29 October 2010, Talu said, “We are casting 1,500 cubic meters of [[concrete]] every day. We have driven 4,500 meters of piles into the ground. A labour force of above 350 workers is busy at the construction site 24 hours a day. The stadium is going to be so strong that it may even be used as a catastrophe relief center if required." Talu said the project being contemplated on the land in Mecidiyeköy in lieu of the old Ali Sami Yen Stadium will be initiated in June 2009, and added, “the mixed-use development project that we are going to build on land measuring 34,600 square meters will include apartments, a large shopping center, offices and a five-star hotel. A total of $650 million will be invested in these two projects, and in return, we expect an income of about $1.3 billion when the Mecidiyeköy mixed-use complex is completed. Therefore, this is a highly profitable venture." The total stadium construction is expected to cost around US$191 million, not including the US$145+ million which will be spend on upgrading the nearby infrastructure. The construction of the stadium stopped twice a time. When Talu had financial problems once again, TOKİ cancelled the process in July 2009.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/spor/futbol/11987786.asp |title=TOKÄ° Seyrantepe Projesi'ni iptal etti – Futbol Haberleri |website=Hurriyet.com.tr |date=2009-02-07 |accessdate=2016-08-08}} After termination of TOKİ-Talu agreement, TOKİ announced a new auction. Varyap-Uzunlar consortium won the auction{{cite web|url=http://www.emlakkulisi.com/22375_varyap-uzunlar_seyrantepe_de_one_cikti_ |title=Varyap-Uzunlar Seyrantepe'de öne çıktı! |website=Emlakkulisi.Com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08}} and construction restarted in September 2009. Galatasaray and TOKİ had an agreement that the stadium would be opened without retractable roofs which will be installed at the end of the season.Dilek Taş, [http://www.sabah.com.tr/Ekonomi/2010/07/23/seyrantepenin_catisini_galatasaray_kapatacak "Seyrantepe'nin çatısını Galatasaray kapatacak"], ''[[Sabah (newspaper)|Sabah]]'', 23 July 2010. ===Groundbreaking ceremony=== [[File:Türk Telekom Arena yapım aşaması.JPG|thumb|300px|Site preparation (March 2006)]] As of 13 December 2007, the construction has officially started after a glitzy reception where the club's board, some players, the minister of sports for [[Turkey]] and many other ministers attended. In the ceremony, then President [[Özhan Canaydın]] stated, in summary: "The Turkish World of Sports will gain another big facility with the Ali Sami Yen Sports Complex and we've gathered here to celebrate its groundbreaking ceremony. This work, which will be a value add to Istanbul and Turkey along with Turkish Sports, will also serve as an honorable monument that will signify the advanced position Turkish Sports has achieved and the phases it has passed through."[http://www.galatasaray.org/english/detail.asp?PID=1160&HID=1&haberID=302796] {{dead link|date=August 2016}} === Name === The [[naming rights]] were sold to [[Türk Telekom]] for a period of 10 years for US$10.25 million a year. The stadium has officially replaced the [[Ali Sami Yen Stadium]] at the middle of the 2010–2011 [[Süper Lig]] season, under the name of '''Türk Telekom Arena'''. North tribune's name of this stadium were sold to [[Pegasus Airlines]] for €4 million a year. The contract ended in October 2013.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.flypgs.com/pegasus-hakkinda/haberler/365/pegasus-hava-yollari-arenada.aspx|title=Pegasus Hava Yolları – Ucuz Uçak Bileti Demek Özgürlük Demek | Pegasus Hava Yolları|website=Flypgs.com|date=|accessdate=2016-08-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229184747/http://www.flypgs.com/pegasus-hakkinda/haberler/365/pegasus-hava-yollari-arenada.aspx|archivedate=2010-12-29|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://fossacimbom.blogspot.com/2010/07/pegasus-aslantepeye-sponsor-oldu.html |title=FCN Blog: Pegasus Aslantepe'ye sponsor oldu |website=Fossacimbom.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08}} The naming rights of the first tier of the east tribune of Türk Telekom Stadium were also sold to [[Ülker]] for $2 million a year and will be named as ''Ülker Family Tribune''.[http://mobil.haberturk.com/emlak-mortgage/haber/537706-cimboma-yilda-90-milyon-dolar-kazandiracak] {{dead link|date=August 2016}} All 198 suites' and 4,844 VIP seats' naming rights were sold to [[Denizbank]] for three years.{{cite web |url=http://www.gsdenizclub.com/haber.php?id=3726 |title=Welcome gsdenizclub.com - BlueHost.com |website=Gsdenizclub.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160821075408/http://www.gsdenizclub.com/haber.php?id=3726 |archivedate=2016-08-21 |df= }} On 18 December 2012 Galatasaray SK and [[Opel]] signed a 2.5-year contract for the naming rights of the Southstand.{{cite web|title=Opel Now Also Galatasaray Istanbul Partner|url=http://media.opel.com/media/intl/en/opel/news.detail.html/content/Pages/news/intl/en/2013/opel/04-09-partner-istanbul.html|publisher=OPEL|accessdate=17 April 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.galatasaray.org/kulup/haber/15458.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-04-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130129071132/http://www.galatasaray.org/kulup/haber/15458.php |archivedate=2013-01-29 |df= }} The Club will receive €1.5 million per year (€3.75 million in total).{{cite web|url=http://www.galatasaray.org/sportif/haber/16069.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102144605/http://www.galatasaray.org/sportif/haber/16069.php |archivedate=2013-11-02 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://skorer.milliyet.com.tr/opel-den-3-5-yil-icin-5-6-milyon/galatasaray/detay/1643740/default.htm |title=Opel’den 3.5 yıl için 5.6 milyon |website=Skorer.milliyet.com.tr |date=2012-12-18 |accessdate=2016-08-08}} On 24 September 2013 Galatasaray SK and [[Odeabank]] signed a five-year contract (€590,000 a year) for naming rights to the Northstand.{{cite web|url=http://www2.galatasaray.org/kulup/haber/17985.ph |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-10-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101063314/http://www2.galatasaray.org/kulup/haber/17985.ph |archivedate=2013-11-01 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.kap.gov.tr/bildirim-sorgulari/bildirim-detayi.aspx?id=317347 |title=KAP |website=KAP.gov.tr |date=2013-10-31 |accessdate=2016-08-08}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- !Stand ! |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08}} ===Additions=== ====2012==== In time for the 2012–13 season the club added 41 new suites at the North Corners of Level 4. So the total amount raised from 157 to 198, making it second in Europe behind [[Estadio Santiago Bernabeu]] which has got 245 suites.{{cite web|url=http://www.realmadrid.com/en/santiago-bernabeu-stadium |title=Santiago Bernabéu Stadium | Real Madrid CF |website=Realmadrid.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08}} The capacity decreased from 52,652 to 52,223. ====2018 - Hybrid grass==== In January 2018 a [[Hybrid grass|SISGrass]] hybrid pitch was relaid to improve the pitch quality.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/IvoLamot/status/953292789340688384 |title=Twitter account of SIS worker Ivo Lamot|website=twitter.com |date= |accessdate=2018-01-16}} ==Concerts== [[File:Turk Telekom Arena Bon Jovi Concert.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Bon Jovi]] concert on 8 July 2011]] The stadium can also be turned into a concert arena with a capacity for over 70,000 people. The first band to play at Türk Telekom Stadium was [[Bon Jovi]] on 8 July 2011.[http://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=113682168720651]{{dead link|date=August 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://backstagewithjon.bonjovi.com/story/news-live-announcements/bon_jovi_2011_open_air_tour__comes_to_istanbul |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-06-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120707101331/http://backstagewithjon.bonjovi.com/story/news-live-announcements/bon_jovi_2011_open_air_tour__comes_to_istanbul |archivedate=2012-07-07 |df= }} The second singer at the stadium was [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], who performed on 7 June 2012 as part of her [[MDNA Tour]]. She played in front of 47,789 fans.[https://www.webcitation.org/69CpvAHLx?url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/charts/currentboxscore.jsp] == Surroundings == [[File:Maslak'tan TT Arena.jpg|thumb|300px]] === Aslanlı Yol === From the Seyrantepe Metro Station just east of the stadium, visitors approach the stadium through a road called ''Aslanlı Yol'', which was designed to disentangle and guide them to the entrance. It is 200 meters long and 45 meters wide. Ticket sales, Simit Sarayı Restaurant and Yüzevler Restaurant are also located at the ''Aslanlı Yol''. ===Aslantepe GSStore=== On 7 February 2012 a new GS Store opened next to the stadium.{{cite web |url=http://www.galatasaray.org/kulup/haber/12461.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120427182705/http://www.galatasaray.org/kulup/haber/12461.php |archivedate=2012-04-27 |df= }} It has got a similar architecture and was designed by Galatasaray SK project coordinator Coşkun Peküstün and the architect Ayşegül Uslu.{{cite web |url=http://v2.arkiv.com.tr/p11268-turk-telekom-arena-gs-store.html |title=Türk Telekom Stadium GS Store |website=V2.arkiv.com.tr |date=2012-05-15 |accessdate=2016-08-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160920095054/http://v2.arkiv.com.tr/p11268-turk-telekom-arena-gs-store.html |archive-date=2016-09-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }} it is built on a 950 m² area and the floor area is 1,650 m². It has got two floor, while the first floor is used for the retail and the second the ''Ülker Fan Zone''. == Transportation == Türk Telekom Stadium is served by a number of bus routes and the shuttle line of [[Istanbul Metro|Metro]] [[M2 (Istanbul Metro)|M2]], which runs from the Sanayi Mahallesi Station to Seyrantepe at the stadium.{{cite web |url=http://www.ibb.gov.tr/tr-TR/Pages/Haber.aspx?NewsID%3D19048 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-06-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303220312/http://www.ibb.gov.tr/tr-TR/Pages/Haber.aspx?NewsID=19048 |archivedate=2011-03-03 |df= }} There are four four-story [[Multi-storey car park|parking garages]] with 3,225 (3,025 covered and 200 open) parking places. In addition, there are also 28 places available for buses at the west entrance. == GS Bonus Card == GS Bonus Card is the stadium card of Galatasaray SK which can also be used as a credit card. Unified [[Radio-frequency identification|RFID]] cards are used as season tickets at Türk Telekom Stadium. The card can be used for all services at the stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.bonus.com.tr/pages/kart-cesitleri-bonus-galatasaray.aspx |title=GS Bonus | Kredi Kartı | Garanti Bonus |website=Bonus.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08}}{{cite web |url=http://www.galatasaray.org/gsbonus/haber/5342.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727142826/http://www.galatasaray.org/gsbonus/haber/5342.php |archivedate=2010-07-27 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://ntvspor.net/haber/futbol/21201/gs-bonus-card-bir-ilke-imza-atiyor |title=GS Bonus Card bir ilke imza atıyor |website=NTVSpor.net |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08}} ==Records== ===Attendance=== *The highest attendance recorded at Türk Telekom Stadium was 52,044 for an [[UEFA Champions League]] quarter-final match between Galatasaray and [[Real Madrid CF]] on 9 April 2013. *The highest attendance for a [[Süper Lig]] match is 51,983, between [[Galatasaray SK]] and [[Trabzonspor]] on 18 May 2013. *The highest attendance for a non-competitive game is 40,000, set on 15 January 2011 for a pre-season testimonial between Galatasaray and [[AFC Ajax]]. *The highest attendance for a [[Türkiye Kupası]] match is 31,930, set on 2 March 2011, when Galatasaray played against [[Gaziantepspor]]. *The highest attendance for a national team match is 49,532. Set on 7 October 2011, when [[Turkey national football team|Turkey]] played against [[Germany national football team|Germany]]. * The highest attendance for a concert is 47,789. Set on 7 June 2012, when Madonna performed a concert as part of her MDNA Tour. ===List=== {| class="wikitable" |+ ''' ''' ! Rank!! Attendance !! Date !! (football team)|Galatasaray SK]] – [[Trabzonspor]] |- ! 3 |align=center| 51,793 || 5 May 2013 || [[Galatasaray S.K. (football team)|Galatasaray SK]] – [[Sivasspor]] |- ! 4 |align=center| 51,567 || 22 April 2012 || [[Galatasaray S.K. (football team)|Galatasaray SK]] – [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football team)|Fenerbahçe SK]] |- ! 6 | align=center| 51,350|| 6 April 2014|| [[Galatasaray S.K. (football team)|Galatasaray SK]] – [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football team)|Galatasaray SK]] – [[Beşiktaş J.K]] |} ===Loudest crowd=== On March 18, 2011, the Türk Telekom Stadium recorded 131.76 [[decibel]]s which was considered to be the world record for "loudest crowd roar at a sport stadium" in [[Guinness World Records]]{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.de/world-records/1/loudest-crowd-roar-at-a-sports-stadium |title=Guinness World Records |website=Guinnessworldrecords.de |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08}}{{cite web |url=http://www.galatasaray.org/kulup/haber/9599.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110320225941/http://www.galatasaray.org/kulup/haber/9599.php |archivedate=2011-03-20 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://i52.tinypic.com/9u2l1l.jpg |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120926223642/http://i52.tinypic.com/9u2l1l.jpg |archivedate=2012-09-26 |df= }} The record has since then been raised by [[National Football League|NFL]] [[American football]] games starting with September 15, 2013 at [[CenturyLink Field]] in a [[Seattle Seahawks]] game that reached 136.6 decibels;{{cite web|last=Kreamer |first=Matt |url=http://blogs.seattletimes.com/today/2013/09/centurylink-is-guinness-world-records-loudest-stadium/#.UjZt74b3TQE.facebook |title=CenturyLink is Guinness World Record's loudest stadium | The Today File | Seattle Times |website=Blogs.seattletimes.com |date=2013-09-15 |accessdate=2016-08-08}} on October 13, 2013 at [[Arrowhead Stadium]] in a [[Kansas City Chiefs]] game that reached 137.5 dB,;{{cite news|last=Kaduk|first=Kevin|title=Arrowhead Stadium sets loudest crowd record after Chiefs fans hit 137.5 decibels|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/nfl-shutdown-corner/arrowhead-stadium-reclaims-title-world-loudest-stadium-chiefs-211332866--nfl.html|accessdate=13 October 2013|newspaper=Yahoo! Sports|date=13 October 2013}} again at [[CenturyLink Field]] on December 2, 2013, with 137.6 decibels;{{cite web|author=Frank Schwab |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/nfl-shutdown-corner/seahawks-back-guinness-world-record-crowd-noise-137-030804215--nfl.html |title=Seahawks take back the Guinness World Record for crowd noise at 137.6 decibels |website=Sports.yahoo.com |date=2013-12-03 |accessdate=2016-08-08}} and most recently reclaimed by [[Arrowhead Stadium]] on September 29, 2014 in a game that reached 142.2 dB.{{cite web|title=It's official! 142.2 is a new Guinness World Record.|url=https://www.facebook.com/KansasCityChiefs/photos/a.331510263372.187547.11373923372/10152747780633373/?type=1&theater|website=facebook.com|publisher=Kansas City Chiefs|accessdate=30 September 2014}}{{cite web|author=Tyler Brooke |url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2215330-kansas-city-chiefs-break-seattle-seahawks-record-of-loudest-outdoor-stadium |title=Kansas City Chiefs Break Seattle Seahawks' Record of Loudest Outdoor Stadium |publisher=[[Bleacher Report]] |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08}} ==Matches== ===Turkish National Team=== {{main|Turkey national football team}} Demand was 65,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.aksam.com.tr/spor/galatasaray/aslandan-rekor-46-bin-kombine-75-milyon-gelir/haber-229893 |title=Galatasaray'dan rekor gelir |website=Aksam.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2016-08-08}} ==Gallery== {{wide image|Ali Sami Yen Spor Kompleksi Türk Telekom Arena2.jpg|800px|align-cap=center|A panoramic view of the interior}} {{wide image|GS-FB 3-1 Panorama.jpg|800px|align-cap=center|Galatasaray – Fenerbahçe 3–1, 7 December 2011 }} File:Türk Telekom Arena Dressing Room.jpg|Dressing Room File:Türk Telekom Arena Press Room.jpg|Press Room File:Türk Telekom Arena Lounge.jpg|VIP Lounge File:Türk Telekom Arena Suite.jpg|Suite File:Ali Sami Yen Spor Kompleksi Galatasaray Store Interior view 1.JPG|Galatasaray Store File:Ali Sami Yen Spor Kompleksi Galatasaray Store.JPG|Galatasaray Store File:Ali Sami Yen Spor Kompleksi Türk Telekom Arena3.jpg|Aslanlı Yol File:Taksim metrosu.jpg|Aslantepe Metro Station ==See also== *[[List of football stadiums in Turkey]] *[[Istanbul bid for the 2020 Summer Olympics]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Türk Telekom Arena}} *{{en icon}} [http://www.galatasaray.org/en/turktelekomarena Club information on new stadium] *{{tr icon}} [http://www.turktelekomarena.com.tr Türk Telekom Stadium Official WebSite] *{{tr icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20121010145123/https://gucumuzsizsiniz.com/Default.aspx Türk Telekom Stadium Official Ticket WebSite] *[http://www.wikimapia.org/#lat=41.1056138&lon=28.9946795&z=16&l=0&m=s Türk Telekom Stadium on Wikimapia] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080106205416/http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_menu/past_future/pictures/future_stadiums/istanbul_yen.shtml Design of stadium] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[FIFA U-20 World Cup]]

{{Infobox football club | clubname = US Fonctionnaires | image = | fullname = Union Sportive des Fonctionnaires | nickname = | founded = | ground = [[Mahamasina Stadium]]
[[Antananarivo]], [[Madagascar]] | capacity = 22,000 | chairman = | manager = {{flagicon|Madagascar}} Sander Robson | league = [[Malagasy Second Division]] | season = 2013 | position = | }} '''Union Sportive des Fonctionnaires''' is a [[Madagascar|Malagasy]] [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Antananarivo]], [[Madagascar]]. The team has won the [[THB Champions League]] in 1969, qualifying them for the [[1970 African Cup of Champions Clubs]].http://www.rsssf.com/tablesm/madagchamp.html The team currently plays in the [[Malagasy Second Division]]. ==Achievements== *'''[[THB Champions League]]''' :Champion (1): 1969 ==Performance in CAF competitions== *'''[[CAF Champions League]]: 1 appearance''' ::[[1970 African Cup of Champions Clubs|1970]] – first round ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[[:pl:US Fonctionnaires]] [[Category:Football clubs in Madagascar]] [[Category:Antananarivo]] {{Madagascar-footyclub-stub}}

The '''Uruguay men's national water polo team''' is the representative for [[Uruguay]] in international men's [[water polo]].
